All Reviews

  1. OW! Not easy to use, has to be at the perfect angle to remove hair. It's a more time-intensive and painful alternative to shaving.
  2. I've been using Phillips epilator for over 15 years and they are the best!
  3. Just what I expected. I didn't have any problems with pulling, pinching or any other issues I read others had. I feel this is a quality product.
  4. Works as it says, but the only downside is that I wish it was cordless!
  5. Love it. No problems, have been using similar products for years, so no pain or maybe just use to the little sting of having the hairs pulled out from the root. Enjoy the smooth feel and well worth it.
  6. LOVE LOVE LOVE<br />Way less messier than waxing with the same results and little pain.
  7. Clip hair, unaccustomed
  8. I'm not pleased that the description states: &#34;Cordless epilator gives you soft, smooth skin head-to-toe,&#34; when it's not cordless at all. It MUST be plugged into the cord to operate. Overall, it works okay, but ensure your hair is long enough for the epilator to grip and you are using it in a well-lit room.
  9. I love it made my hairs grow in thinner, its a little painful but its worth the pain. I recommend it.
  10. Good machine and easy to use with good results
  11. This thing is fantastic! My daughter borrowed mine, and loved it so much, I had to buy her one, so I could have mine back. Then a week later, my daughter-in-law borrowed it, with the same results. So far, I have purchased 3 of these. I will admit, that the first time you use it, it is a little painful. Not too bad, but definitely a little uncomfortable. This is because you are pulling out hairs from the root, and these roots have been established for some time. After the first couple of times, it is much better. After the first few times, you only have to use it about once every week or week and a half. The other positive is that when your hair does start growing back in a week later, it is very fine and light colored, not dark and coarse. So far the girls have only used it on their legs. I was brave enough to use it on my armpits, where I have even better results. Armpits are a very tender area when you are pulling hairs, so the first couple of times, it might bring a few tears to your eyes, but it is soooooo worth it!!! I can use it on my armpits, and a week later, they are still smooth as can be. I told the girls they have to try it. This epilator is the best thing ever!!!
  12. All girls should buy it
  13. Se recibio el pedido muy bien en Venezuela
  14. This has been my first epilator, so I have nothing to compare it to. Yes it is painful but not as bad as everyone acts like it is. My main problem with it is that is doesn't get all the hairs. I spent forever doing my legs and I didn't even get all of them. So I don't really even use it anymore. I'll probably just buy a more expensive one, or go back to shaving.
  15. Have had it quite a while now and it still works pretty well. You have to go over quite a bit but I think that happens with most epilators.
  16. I bought this to replace an old epilator that had just plain worn out. Love it! It is quiet and pulls those facial hairs out with minimal discomfort. Much easier than manual plucking. I love a smooth face!
  17. It is small and compact. Does the job quickly.
  18. Disappointed that the priced increased $5.00 while in my cart ... I guess to make up for the $5.00 coupon that was clipped. That seems a bit shady :-/
  19. I recently bought this product so I could remove hair that I didn't want, and I was tired of shaving and wasting money on razors all the time. This epilator does its job, I'll tell you that. It removes all the hairs straight from the root. Here are pros/cons and my first impressions, overall, I like this thing, but nothing is perfect.<br /><br />Pros:<br />-Removes hair from the root (no more shaving)<br />-Slows the re-growth of the hair down over time<br />-Leaves your skin nice and smooth<br />-No more \\"stubs\\" and \\"prickles\\" on the skin after a few days<br />-Smoothness lasts at least 2-3 weeks<br />-Inexpensive and easy<br /><br />Cons:<br />-It hurts A LOT! (It's different for others, i'm sure)<br />-Skin got irritated afterwards<br />-Took a long time to remove every single hair<br /><br />So, that's that. My first problem with this thing, and the obvious thing, is that this plucks out all of your hairs, so this is no painless experience. It is probably different for others, but for me, it hurt like crazy. I'm guessing if you have never pulled your hair from the root in the past, you will feel it. I could feel the hairs being ripped out, and honestly, I started shaking and sweating from the pain. I think it was worth it though, because in the long run, no more shaving!<br /><br />This thing requires time and patience. It does NOT do its job just buy going over once. It took me three times to remove every single hair from my legs. I even had to wait a day or two and go back over again, but over time, it will be less time consuming.<br /><br />I found that I got redness afterwards. This appeared normal, so all I did was but some aloe lotion on and took and ice pack and rubbed it up against my skin. It really helped. After about 12 hours, the redness was all gone, so I think that redness afterwards is probably normal.<br /><br />Overall, I really like this product and will continue using it. It took time to adapt, so don't give up on it too early, give it some time.
  20. really great for the price

The only thing that I don't like is that it is so loud! also it's big but doesn't pull out as much hair at a time as i wish it would.<br /><br />None the less I would recommend.

  32. Not a solid brand, but what do you expect for that price. I guess you get what you pay for. I use this one as my quick, secondary one. I love my solid and sturdy Emjoi red one. My old Braun one was good, it had a light and was solid, but eventually the motor wore out.
  33. For me, it works well for underarms. Not much of pain and it plucks well. But for legs - my hair on legs is very thin and not much, it just creates many bumps. I think it cuts hair rather than plucking. It makes ingrown hair a lot. I think this is only good for coarse hair.

Now, it does hurt. Not horribly, but like little pricks with a needle. I used it on my boyfriend's arm & he said it felt like a light tattoo needle. I thought for sure it was scratching my skin, but it was just the pain of several hairs being pulled out at the root. Legs were slightly red the next day, but that's about it. I hate shaving because my hair grows too fast & it's a hassle to shave every day or every other day. I put it on the slowest setting because I find that it works better. I did have to go over some areas a few times, but it's worth it to not have to shave. WARNING: USING THIS ON YOUR UNDERARMS HURTS!!! MEGA PAIN & MY SKIN WAS SORE THE NEXT DAY.   42. This is actually my first epilator so I am still getting used to it. My first time it took me two hours, second time 1 hr and so on. The more you use it, the more you’re legs are desensitised to the pain, hence the quicker you can use it. Now to describe the pain associated with this product. It’s basically that feeling where someone is pulling out your hair, but many at a time. The back of my calves and near the ankles hurt more than the other parts of my leg. I haven’t yet ventured out to use it anywhere else.<br /><br />After researching online, I found out that exfoliation is a must, so I exfoliated a day before wanting to use this epilator. But as I was just a beginner, I didn’t stick to the routine which lead to ingrown hair. But for newbies like me, as long as you exfoliate regularly, it shouldn’t be a problem.<br /><br />This product would have been more ideal if it came with some instructions or tips which guide you through what to do before and after epilation. It would have helped me save a lot of time I had spent scouring the internet for tips.<br />Another thing which put me off is the noise it made. It sounded like a saw, so I always put my headphones on and listen to some upbeat music to help distract me a little =)<br /><br />The product was definitely not what I was expecting. I expected pain, pain and more pain! So I was extremely happy to find out this wasn’t the case! =) Though painful, it is something which can be handled. Quite happy I bought this.

The pros: smooth skin, convenient, less pain, no redness/swelling; the cons: very time consuming as you have to epilate individual areas instead of removing hair from a large area the way waxing works - however, that is a negative about epilation in general.   60. Let me start off by saying that I have been in two wars. This fiendish device makes Iraq and Afghanistan look like Disneyland in comparison. It appeared harmless enough; small, compact, and feminine. That all immediately changed once I plugged it in and turned it on. It sounds exactly like how I imagined the maw to Hell itself sounding. It’s basically a hand-held wood chipper. I thought to myself “no ****ing way”. But curiosity eventually got the best of me and I went for it. I almost blacked out from the pain; it was as if each hair follicle was being yanked directly out of my soul. I should have ended it there and walked away, but I had to keep my eye on the prize of having a smooth groin area. Hoping that my deceased relatives weren’t somehow witnessing this from Heaven - I laid down in the bath tub, took a swig of whiskey, kissed my rosary beads, bit down on a piece of leather, and went for it. After a while, your brain eventually tells your body to **** off and you get used to the pain. If being smooth down there is worth intense pain to you, then I recommend this product.

  70. This is the first epilator I've ever owned. I have very low tolerance for pain and always go for the most expensive product on the shelf. This time, I thought I will give this epilator a go. It really wasn't as painful as everybody said it was.<br />Tips:<br />1. Apply some oil (I use Sweet Almond Oil) before you epilate. Some people say you have to make sure your skin is complete oil free before epilating. I totally disagree because epliating on dry skin hurts like ****.<br />2. Be sure the epilator is at 90degrees to your skin, otherwise you might get broken hair.<br />3. Apply some more oil after you epilate. You will not feel any pain after. It is pain free!!<br /><br />Things I did wrong:<br />I used some Veet wax strips first so trim my underarm hoping to reduce pain during my epilation process. DO NOT DO THIS. The waxing process was so painful and I was still left with a lot of hair (now my 1 star review will go there). Then I used this epilator. Can you believe it? It was at least 10 times less painful than those waxing strips and did not leave a trace of a hair on my underarm. I could clearly see that the waxed areas still had dark roots but those epilated areas were white and clean. Next time I might try them on the chicken wings I get from the supermarket because the supermarket doesn't seem to do a good enough job waxing my chicken, comparing to this Epilator does my underarms.

I haven't attempted the bikini line-underarm was painful enough.<br /><br />Overall, it works but there may be more effective (albeit a bit pricier) options.   105. This has been a great epilator so far! I bought this one hoping it would be more durable than the Emjoi ones. I had the [[ASIN:B003II4D2C Emjoi Divine Hair Remover, White/Pink]], it worked well - about the same as this Philips one. Then I got [[ASIN:B001GS6OB4 Emjoi AP-18 Emagine Dual Opposed 72 Tweezer Head Epilator]] This one is probably my favorite because it is so much faster than the single barrel ones. But it eventually broke within a year, so then I bought the men's version: [[ASIN:B003H3G470 Emjoi AP-18MS Emagine Epilator for Men, Black]] This one is pretty much the same, slightly different shape but it also broke after a few months. So then I bought the Emagine Dual Emjoi again, and it broke again. So I finally ended up with this Philips that I have now. I feel like this one is well made and it seems to pick up slightly more hair and finer hairs. Even if I found another good one with a lot more tweezers, I will probably keep this Philips one around because its great for the areas that need something smaller and more precise. My opinion on these is not based on pain. Epilating and waxing hurt regardless of the method, I have tried just about every method myself over the years. When you get used to these methods of hair removal, they don't hurt as much. Epilating hurts me especially badly when I put off doing it for several weeks or if my skin is cold, but it always hurts more at first then gets better. Just do a little at a time to begin with. After epilating/waxing for years, the hair grows thinner, finer, and less dense and therefore hurts less as time goes on. So if you're like me and you've never found a way for shaving to work for you, then give epilating a try. Go slow, have a strong drink, pat your skin where it hurts, put on some music, and chill - you'll get used to it. All the Emjoi ones have broke on me for the same reason. The epilator gets hung up on skin that is too thick or something like that and the plastic gears inside get stripped out. My dream epilator would have 72 tweezers (or close - the little single barrel ones take way too long), be CORDED (because the rechargable batteries do not work nearly long enough/ produce enough power), and be durable enough to last a reasonable amount of time without breaking. I don't care about all the extra heads, massagers, lights, etc etc. I never have a use for any of it. I have not found an epilator that fully meets these standards.

  112. My husband bought this item for me so I am writing the review hoping that someone will find this helpful. Before we bought this epilator, I read so many reviews and compared different brands and style. I am very glad that I made the decision to get this one. First of all, this is very affordable compared to the other ones out there. But although it is cheaper, the quality is really good. Very simple to use. For my experience, it is not so painful mainly because of the smaller number of tweezers. It is just enough for me to bear the sting. I have been using this for a little over two months now and have used it about 4x since I got it. There were only two instances where I saw a little bit of bleeding (2 red open pores). And this is because there were multiple hair follicles in those particular hair canals (3-4 hair follicles in a single canal) This has nothing to do with the epilator. Just imagine removing those hairs from the roots at the same time, of course there will be a big opened pore afterwards. Thus, the little blood. Some hairs get cut and not pulled from the roots. But I guess this is true with any other epilators. It works perfectly if you use it on the opposite direction where your hair grows, but, sometimes that is hard to do. The good thing is, those few hairs that were not removed from the roots-you can definitely see them grow in a few days and then you can use the epilator again and get better results since they are few and u will definitely see the direction they grow. Although the package says it is for legs only, I use it on my legs, underarms and down there (the top and side part only, I still use wax on the sentitive part). The product is very safe to use. I actually tried to push it hard against my skin to test if it will hurt or get a bit of my skin but it did not. I would definitely recommend this to anyone looking for an affordable but good quality basic epilator.
  113. Jan 7, 2015: I previously had a Braun epilator and compared to that, the plastic on the inside of this epilator seemed &#34;cheap.&#34; The product also gave off a strong, nasty odor of some kind. Still, I give it 5 stars because it is not meant to be pleasant-smelling or seem sturdy, it has to get the job done and that it does perfectly. Though it is to be used on legs, I used it on my face too with satisfactory results. I have coarse hair on my legs and it required many passes to completely remove the hair, but rarely the hair broke. I did not use the safety attachment and wish it had a brush instead. In the instructions, I found the risk of shock part scary.<br /><br />Update, March 12, 2015: I have had the epilator for more than two months now and it is showing signs of wear. It is taking several passes to pull out the hair. I have used it a lot; however, it may still be a good choice for someone who uses it moderately, seeing as the price has dropped further since I bought it.

  115. Awesome! It totally met my expectations! It does a great job! First time it can hurt a little.. But after that you will love it!
  116. Great little epilator...hair removal devise. Basically, we're talking a bunch of little tweezers plucking at once to remove hair from you body. I can't truthfully say it's painless, but it's not that bad either. It's quick and over before you know it. And the skin is so smooth afterwards. The hair that grows back is finer and shorter. I'd recommend it.

  121. When I first tried this product, I was a little disappointed because it seemed to break the hair off at skin-level. But it was entirely my fault. I basically ripped open the package and went for it. The second time, I followed the instructions more fully and made sure my legs were clean and well-exfoliated, before I had applied any lotion to them. Also, holding the skin taught helps a lot, too. It works really well! However, my legs have never had that &#34;just shaved&#34; smoothness since I started epilating. I always feel like I have a tiny amount of stubble, even if my legs don't look like they need a shave. I used the guard for the first several times, but found that it helped me learn how to hold the machine, and by the third or fourth time using it, I was able to remove it and it worked even better. For me (I have fine, blonde hair), a light, slow, motion works best. Just try it a few different ways and see what works best for you and your hair type.<br /><br />There is no doubt that it is uncomfortable to use this product, especially the first few times you use it. It feels like tiny little bee stings all over your skin. It's ripping your hair out by the roots; it's not going to be painless. But it is something you grow accustomed to. You sort of become numbed to the sensation. After using it for a few weeks, I decided to get brave and try it on my underarms. I knew what sort of sensation to expect, held the skin taught, and went for it. It worked fantastically well! My underarms have never felt so smooth.<br /><br />I quite like this product and would recommend it. Just make sure to completely read and follow the instructions, and you'll be fine.
  122. Disappointing product. I bought it to use for my legs. It doesn't do its job. It just breaks the hairs halfway and it doesn't grab all hairs. Also, in order to use it you need to have the product plugged into an outlet. Cordless product would be much nicer than this one.

I wasn't solving that issue buying this cheaper one that has to be plugged in, no battery to charge to begin with... but I figured I'd at least get a newer model that works better than my 6 year old one. NOPE! This was a complete waste of money. I do not recommend this product in any way. I don't know if paying more would get better, but I do know this item just plain doesn't do its job.

I intended on using it on my legs too but that took too long for me to keep it up, and I was left with a bunch of ingrown hairs so I'll stick to waxing/shaving my legs for now.

  132. I have always gone the waxing route. It is quite painful and pretty expensive. I bought this epilator to give it a try. I checked out a few youtube videos and Amazon reviews and some people had mentioned that it is extremely painful. On the other hand, I was happy with the experience. It is kind of painful, no doubt about it. But for people who are used to waxing, you won't find it any more painful than waxing. Do follow the instructions where they suggest epilation after a shower. I think that helps. The efficiency cap also helps to some extent. Some of the cons in my opinion - 1. Takes a lot of time to epilate 2. This did not come with a cleaning brush, so I had to make-do with something that I already had. Overall, I recommend this product.

  135. You're pulling your hair out by the roots, it's just a slower means of waxing. But if you already know what to expect, then it's tolerable.<br /><br />I'm impatient, so I used it the day I got it rather than doing any prep work--I just exfoliated in the shower beforehand. I wasn't sure how bad it would be, given the mixed reviews--the first pass was rather startling. I had to warm myself up to it (literally, I rubbed the area I was working on with a cloth to help open up the pores and desensitise my skin), but I was able to do all of both legs, as well as my underarms (the product states that it's only intended to be used on legs, so don't take that as any kind of validation). My legs did feel the tiniest bit stubbly afterwards, possibly from some hairs being broken instead of pulled, but it was better than my electric razor can do.<br />It's been ten days and I'm only now noticing new hair growth. It's supposed to become easier as your skin gets used to it, and the hairs grow in finer, so I'm looking forward to my second go-around.<br /><br />If I decide to continue epilating, I'll probably invest in a wet/dry model, since the heat and lubrication seem like they'd make things smoother. It also didn't even occur to me that this would need to stay plugged in, so many things are cordless nowadays. This is a decent basic model, but definitely seems like something worth putting a little extra money into.

  137. It cuts hairs rather than pulling. Also does not get as much. I much much prefer the Emjoi Emagine Dual 72 tweezer.
  138. This was my first time epilating, so I'm not sure how it compares to other epilators, but I have to say I'm not too impressed with the experience. The pain I don't find particularly disturbing, and my skin tolerates it well- not too many bumps or ingrown hairs. However, the product itself is just not that effective. It seems to break off a lot of the hairs instead of pulling them out. I've tried many ways- different lengths of hair, different speeds and techniques, after showering, after exfoliating, all the tips I've been able to find, but it still just breaks most of the hairs off. When I rub my hands over my legs it feels like the second or so day after shaving, very stubbly. I can even look closely and see the tiny hairs broken off at the skin, too short to be picked up by the epilator. Also, you have to go over and over and over a spot for it to pick up all the hairs, and therefore it takes a long time. I usually do it while watching a tv show, and it isn't unexpected to spend 30-40 minutes on my legs, just up to my knee! And then still have stubble? Sheesh, I could have just shaved in 5 minutes and be smooth. Plus, because it leaves so many broken off hairs the regrowth is just as bad as shaving. The only thing really positive I can say about this epilator is the regrowth does feel significantly softer than after shaving, though I don't know why. At any rate, I'm giving this to my mother whose not too concerned about smooth legs or missing a few hairs and I think I'm going to try a different epilator before I give up entirely on the technique. If anyone has any suggestions or tips, please let me know! I want to make this work!
  139. I bought this eplilator to remove the hair on my back. I have always shaven the hair off my back. I have never tried an epilator or waxing off the hair. I heard horror stories of how painful epilators were. I read the mixed reviews on this product and decided to give it a try. Holy **** did it hurt! It wasn't an agonizing unbearable pain. It was a quick annoying prickly pain. I had to take several breaks to get the entire hair off my back. I was punching the wall, clapping my hands, yelling, and stomping my feet every time the epilator hit a heavy patch of hair. It took about 20 minutes to get all the hair off my back. Once I was finished, I noticed my back looked cleaner and felt smoother than when I would shave it.<br /><br />As far as the epilator doing a good job removing the hair, it did great. As for the annoying pain I felt from getting the hair removed, it was awful. I don't know if it was because of this particular epilator, since I never used another epilator before. I have a high threshold for pain. I would have rather felt the pain of a broken arm or a sprung ankle than the annoying pain I felt using this thing.<br /><br />A gave the product 4 stars because I didn't know if the pain I felt was from this particular product. However, I did like the results it left and I will try using it again. The product is well worth the price it sells for. I definitely suggest buying the product and giving it a try. Be warned though. It will hurt. I tried the epilator on my arm just to see if it felt as bad (I don't shave my arms). Holy $h!t did it hurt there too.
  140. Hi! This is my very first epilator, and previously all I've ever done for hair removal is shave. Oh, I tweeze my eyebrows. Once I thought to tweeze around the bikini line and after an hour I hadn't accomplished much and gave up. Never had the money to try waxing. My sister had very bad results with Nair.<br /><br />So, my husband bought me this on Amazon- it was inexpensive, but with good reviews for the most part.<br /><br />Well, I have to say I'm amazed! I love this thing. I was very worried about pain, but it's not bad at all for me. Near my ankles is most sensitive (I used it from knee down only so far). Feels like tiny little angry bees, but I can control when they sting me and if it becomes too much, just lift up the machine and it is immediate relief. I was dealing with reflexive urges to jerk away more than the pain itself. My knee didn't care about the epilation at all, just the vibrations on my kneecap was hard, again for that reflexive spasm. Calf area was fine- I felt the little hairs coming out, but it wasn't really painful at all- more like just an indication that yep- another hair just disappeared. I suggest starting higher on a shin, and working your way lower (my hair is also denser toward my ankle).<br /><br />The machine works very well, I think. I have no experience to compare to. The hairs were getting pulled out like magic, and smooth-looking skin was left behind. Yippee! It doesn't FEEL like completely smooth hair-free skin, but it looks like it for sure. Maybe after a few sessions, things will feel smoother? Whatever, if I can have awesome-looking legs, I'm still in love with this machine.<br /><br />I took a shower first, and then dried off and used the epilator. I call this little thing amazing. I tried both speed settings- they don't seem to matter much except one is faster so i had to make fewer passes. I had the little purple \\"efficiency\\" head on it. Not sure what it did except remind me to keep the angle close to 90 degrees. The cap slides off easily to rinse it. I did that, but I don't think I needed to- hair blew loose just fine during use.<br /><br />At first I wished it was battery-operated. I opened the box and immediately thought it needed to be plugged in to charge so I could use it later. Then I realized it doesn't turn on at all unless it is plugged in. I was kind of bummed, until I unwrapped the cord. It is very long and thin, so I had no trouble at all reaching an outlet and still having a comfy spot to sit with my leg propped up. The cord got in my way only once, which is amazing since I switched hands and angles a LOT. I don't consider the lack of a battery a con at all now that I've used it.<br /><br />Just turning on the epilator, it sounds intimidating, but I found that while I was using it, I didn't notice sound at all, and it didn't seem loud to me at all.<br /><br />I wish it came with a nice pouch to put everything in, but I'll just make one :)<br /><br />EDIT:<br />My legs initially did not have any redness or bumps after epilating, but that evening (epilated at about noon) after I was wearing skinny jeans, I took them off to find my legs all red and a little bit tender to the touch like mild razor burn. Sleeping mostly fixed it, and by midday again all was fine.<br /><br />In the shower before epliating my legs, I shaved armpits and pubic area. Today I felt the hair has regrown enough to try epilating those areas. The directions say for legs only- but hair is hair and I'm going to use it where I want no hair to be, so there.<br /><br />Underarms were difficult- you can't really see what you are doing, even using a mirror. Having sweat glands there also meant that moving the epilator smoothly over the skin was not really possible because it kept sticking to the skin. I ended up removing the efficiency cap with it's wide flat area, and this way the rotating of the tweezing disks assisted in smooth forward movement of the epilator. Much better. A few of the lowest pores bled slightly, but nothing major. Nothing hurt overmuch- not as much as the ankle area of my legs.<br /><br />I tried my pubic region next. The hair is much denser there, and doesn't grow quite as fast as my underarms. Still, it was easy to go slowly (left the efficiency cap off) and I tried to keep the skin taunt in one direction or another. I believe the flatter hairs here meant that some tugs of pain were the hair not quite being removed the first time. The edges, even in my leg crease were easy and pain was slight, but near the edges of the labia or \\"lips\\" the hairs are very fine and compact, and it was very tricky to go slowly. That area was sensitive, but not as sensitive as the high edge of the triangle of hair, in the center. I only epilated the main triangle, doing most of the visible hair- down to about level with the beginning of the crease for labia and genitals. The pores in my pubic area did bleed, mostly up high in the sides of the triangle. The hairs coming out were a LOT longer than what was actually showing above the skin.<br /><br />I did not shower beforehand this time, as I feel that the hot water, while it may open pores, also weakens the hair itself, making it more likely to break instead of come out. So I took my shower afterwards this time. The water (and soap) stung my underarms quite painfully (I'd say worse than the epilating). My pubic area didn't care about water, soap, or scrubbing.<br /><br />I'm SO happy I finally purchased one of these!!

  144. For as inexpensive as this little number is I'm not going to complain. This thing works and does the job it just takes a number of passes to get all the hairs, I try going in different directions if it doesn't get them up after the first two initial passes. It is noisy and a little painful depending on your pain tolerance but not unbearable and in my opinion hurts less then if you nick yourself shaving. You control the use and speed (I rarely ever use the second setting), the first couple times I would do small sections at a time and take breaks in between but as you get used to the sensation it's easier to just keep going once you've started. Overall for the price and as a beginner with epilation its a good investment hairs take significantly longer to grow back then they do withat shaving/creams overy time some wont come back at all. I do think I want something that covers a little more surface area (wider with maybe multiple heads) now that I'm used to epilating it's just a matter of shelling out the $$ for a nicer one.
  145. Okay, it's not perfect, I still have a few whispy hairs left after use (are they too short/thin?), but I gleaned that repeated use of this device over time will ultimately be my solution. I've looked pretty hairfree for over a month or two now, and it's been with almost no care or effort on my part. With a razor, you have a perfect full blanket of stubble in 3 days or so and wonder if it's worth it. It hurts like hell on places you're not supposed to use it on. But effective. I'm not yet sure about longterm small marks on the skin, I'm older so it's less of a concern to me. The first time I used it I thought I was going to jump out of my skin and was surprised at how much it hurt, and I've had regular electrology sessions for three years! I've decided I prefer waxing, but can't afford full-body treatments all the time, being on a budget. After a use or two I've grown accustomed to it and it doesn't seem to hurt anymore, until I try it on a new area (the instructions clearly state not to do this). I find it an effective longterm solution. No infected ingrown hairs yet (??) I like the device, it works, it's pretty, convenient, made well, durable, and inexpensive. Definitely a cheaper solution than the others I've tried, and with regular but infrequent maintenance it does the job. I appreciate the review and the tip here that you could do a full shaving first, and then use this periodically as hair begins to grow in. It doesn't get all hairs with each use, it's more of a some here and there or most each time, but over time definitely works and lasts *much* longer, with quick repeated uses here and there maintaining a hairless look indefinitely. I recommend this device, have not tried the others.

  178. I just can't get enough of this product. I have always shaved my legs but over the years my leg hairs started growing faster and darker. I would literally have to shave everyday but would get bad razor burn so I couldn't. Even on the days I shaved, within a few hours I had stubble. It was terrible and I hated it. I had never tried waxing but really wanted to and while looking up waxes, I came across epilators. I read up on it and decided to try the Braun silk epil or something like that. It cost me $100 at target. Needless to say, it didn't work. It broke off a lot of the hairs and was so painful. I couldn't even finish half of one leg. Then I came across this little bad boy, Philips satinelle. I was skeptical at first because if a $100 epilator didn't work, why would a $25 one work...right? I decided to give it a try anyways and so happy that I did. It works! It definitely hurts but not as painful as the Braun. The pain was tolerable. I kept stopping to make sure it was pulling the hairs from the root and it was for sure. It took me a while to get every hair but it's worth it. For the first time in yearssss my legs were silky smooth for more than a day. They stayed smooth for a whole week!!! I couldn't believe it. I'll probably never use a razor on my legs again.
  179. The most I can do with this devil is my underarms. I thought everyone was just being dramatic but this thing hurts like hell. Never again will I purchase an epillator.
  180. I was recommended this product by a friend, and decided to give it a try. It doesn't remove much hair, and you have to go over and over a spot several times to even get close to removing some hair. Compared to other epilators I've seen, this one is simply okay--borderline bad.
  181. I bought it for my wife couple of months ago and she is extremely happy about it so far and thankful..
  182. For the price of this epilator the quality is great! I've only had it a few weeks but it absolutely does the job.
  183. This was my first ever epilator and it worked great for the first month. Now it works have the time so it takes twice as long to finish same area. It is a good size and easy to use though. I feel like I'll need to replace it soon though because it works less and less every time.

  208. This is my first time trying an epilator, however, I have tried at home waxing. When I did try to wax, I was left with welt, redness, and bruising. Although epilating is more painful than you could imagine (it feels like being stabbed with a bunch of needles), it's so much better than shaving! Hair comes in thinner and your legs are smooth for about a week. It doesn't get all of the hair, there is definitely a lot of breakage but I'm sure I'll be able to figure out why in due time. ***UPDATE*** I've changed my four star review to a five star. After giving up because of the pain, I decided to get this baby out again for another round. But this time I did more research! Things that helped ease the pain for me: - Pull your skin taught! - Hold the epilator at a 90 degree angle - Do not press it into your skin - Work in small circles moving the epilator in a circular motion THIS IS THE KEY - Put on some music or a tv show to distract yourself After finding these tricks, I was able to get through both legs. You won't be able to get every hair so I recommend going over your legs again in a few days. The biggest reason why I changed my four star review to a five star review is because the hair grew in finer! Even the course hair! I'm sold.
  209. it is eally hurt and will be blood
  210. Are you a real woman? Have you suffered through your own hymenal rupture, birthed a child or suffered the stinging agony of being rejected by a man? Have you reflected with rue upon a dinner party you ruined through your own juvenile, drunken antics? Then you are ready for this product. It hurts, but it will enchant you for a short while because you want to feel tough. Actually it only hurts the first few times, but then you get used to it. I was excited to try a new method of hair removal. I don't know what my beef is with shaving. I mean, nothing is going to get you smooth like a razor blade. I also thread my eyebrows. You might say I enjoy maximizing my hair removal repertoire, as in my mind this equates with maximizing my womanliness. Your first time: So upon tibial touchdown, I felt an electrifying jolt of pain - much like that of a thousand hairs being torn from their follicles all at once. Enchanted, I continued to wave this magical device over my lower limbs, waiting to see if the pain might be any different if I kept on going, or if it was just going to continue on. It continued on. Soon, however, after several passes, my leg began to feel silky. Not shaved-silky mind you, but more than silky enough. I realized that meant I was done. I was pretty disappointed at the brevity of the encounter, so I promptly moved on to my armpits. The armpits were really fun to do. Did you know your armpit hairs are, like, an inch long? You will, once you use this product! Wow. This thing worked perfectly on my armpits. Better than the legs, and the legs were pretty good. I tentatively moved to the crotch area, but I'd just gotten out of the damn shower and I was too moist for there to be any traction. (Do not try this.) Later, I gave it a shot. Ouchhhhh. It results in a very smooth bikini area, no question. In fact, this product works better on stouter hair. So I moved up to the quintessential delicate area of the upper lip. Like the slap of a burning hot rubber band,my 'stache was GONE. It took several passes, ostensibly because I was a first-timer and my lip hair was unaccustomed to such insult. But you gotta grow up sometime, lip hair. Might as well be today. Still, again, it was not as sleek as a razor by any means. Easily one of the most exciting things about using this product is the sheer volume of hair that comes out of the thing, much like a lawn mower. I've never seen anything like it. And not only the hair comes out, mind you. Oh no. You get the entire hair bulb. I had this friend in high school you know - beautiful girl - and her prom dress was strapless. But she was a full-blooded Italian lass and heaven help her, you could see her dark armpit hair shadow every time she hoisted her arms to do the YMCA, in spite of the fact that it was clear she'd just shaved. This could have done her a world of good. So I will continue using this for pubic and armpit hair (nice long lasting results on the pubic area, somewhat less long lasting on armpits) but I won't be using anything but a razor for legs or stache. First it takes too long, second it is painful, and third you really don't get that sleekness you get from a fresh razor. Still, Recommended highly for how great a job it does on coarse hair. If you have coarse hair all over, this might be a great solution for you. Protip: after epilating, always disinfect. You will get pimples if you do not. Personally I recommend purel even for the pubic area. It burns of course, but you just ripped out the hair on your vagina. What do you care? Also there is a special sphere of heaven for women who can address those stout hairs on the labia area just above the clitoris with an epilator. I can do it. So can you. Actually, I don't recommend this any longer. The hairlessness doesn't seem to last that much longer, and I got tired of infected follicles. I did disinfect the rotating portion of the device regularly, after each use. But the bacteria must hide in all those cracks and crevices. I have returned to shaving. The results are instant, they don't result in pimples, and the effect is, overall, silkier. But heck, give it a try. Much like other aspects of passage into womanhood, first it hurts, then you get used to it, then you sort of like it, and then you get bored with it and try something else.
  211. Quick & easy. I don't need to shave as much anymore & easy to clean. My skin is smoother & has a better appearance. It is like a large tweezer, so if u can't stand the pain of tweeting or waxing, then stick to the razor. Beauty is pain.

I found myself scheduling when to use it so I would not just get the hairs above the skin but give time for the hairs under the skin to come through. Im a college student, so let me just say, I can spend my time doing more productive things. Overall, it didn't really work for me and it wasn't worth the pain. BACK TO SHAVING!

  218. I bought this to replace my other very expensive epilator by emjoi which only lasted a year or two until recently it starts to make this awful squeaky noise and the tweezers in it doesn't turn. It is rechargeable, and for some wierd and unknown reason it doesn't charge up anymore. It only works with the cord. Because of my bad experience with the emjoi brand, I decided to try a much cheaper brand. I am so glad I did. My emjoi cost me close to 100 bucks, as this one which works way better only cost my around $30.<br /><br />This little unit which is so easy to use is unbelievably fast for its small size! Even though it has two speeds, I only use the first one since it is fast enough already. I don't have much need for the second speed yet. I love this one more than my other because it is shaped kind of flat, not fat or chunky like my other epilator, and also very lightweight. Easy to use. I love the size of it most of all which makes it so handy and compact..very simple and easy to travel with. I only wish it came with a travel/storage pouch but that's alright and doesn't bother me at all because I store it in a small, zippered cosmetic bag/purse you can buy anywhere. It's such a nice gadget that I wish the company could have given a small cleaning brush with it as most other epilators do, even though I use the brush that came with my other epilator. This unit only comes with a power cord that is quite long, which is great. It is not rechargeable so you have to use it with the cord plugged in which I like more because my other one was rechargeable and the charge didn't last as long as I wished. Maybe about 40 minutes and sometimes you do need extra time. I recommend a corded epilator. I know it can be harder when you travel as you may not always find an outlet source but I still think it is better since you can give yourself as much time as you need.<br /><br />It works very well, very fast as I said and seems to get the job done in a shorter time period as I did not expect. It does pull out all the hair by the root like waxing. It can be used for the legs, arms, bikini line, underarms, anywhere really. I have only tried it on my legs, arms and even my face which it a little hard due to its size so it is better to get a smaller unit made for the face and smaller areas for that. All epilators, or I should say &#34;Epilation&#34; DOES hurt, maybe even A WHOLE LOT for some, but only in the beginning like your first and/or second attempts. As you epilate more and more, the pain DOES get less and less each time until one day you don't feel any pain at all. Believe me as I have been epilating for years. They do cause ingrown hairs, so as they say, it is more wise to exfoliate in a warm shower beforehand. You can use any exfoliating sponge, mits or soap you can get anywhere. For the redness like bumps on the skin after epilation, use some good creams and the redness will go away. All in all, I highly recommend this epilator for the money. I think cheap or expensive ones all are the same pretty much. I'm glad this one works so well and is great for what I paid. It is great for both men and women. Have fun epilating and enjoy smooth skin! Much better and easier than messy waxing. Faster too!

  222. I got this epilator, because my old one (Remington) got the power plug broken and I thought they do not sell same power plugs, but they do, so now I have two epilators in case one of them breaks down I am not left hairy while shopping for a new one!<br />Anyway, I am very satisfied with this Philips epilator. I did a lot of research online before I decided to buy it and I think I made the right choice. My personal preferences were:<br />1. It has to be usable with and without cord or just with cord. This device comes with a pretty long cord.<br />I know that a lot of newer models come cordless (cord is only for charging), but I have read so many bad reviews about inside batteries dying after just some time of using it that I did not want cordless one. What's the use of it if your battery dies and you cannot use it with cord? Besides my Remington could be used w/wo cord, so that was convenient when it's battery started dying down and it still is when fully used on cord.<br />2. I do not care if it can be used in the shower or have all sorts of extra fancy parts that also comes with appropriate amount of extra $$$.<br /><br />I think this device is really good for the money. The only downside it is pretty loud, my old one is not as loud, but it is pretty bearable.<br />In terms of pain, I think they all inflict some sort of pain, but I am very used to it now anyway, so it is not a big deal for me anyway. I've read somewhere that the least painful time to do it is just after your period, when you body has more tolerance for pain. Not sure if this is true, but you can experiment with it.

  254. There are many contradictory reviews about epilators. Here is yet another review hope it helps:<br /><br />I have waxed before, used too regularly, but got out of the habit. I have been using disposable razors but I am sick of buying more razors every few weeks. Many reviews said the epilator was like waxing in terms of discomfort. This is true. For me, since I know what to expect with waxing the discomfort wasn't shocking. My legs seem to only be sensitive along the shin, and I don't shave my thighs.<br /><br />BE CAREFUL: Do not wipe the pulled out hairs with a terry cloth towel. The tweezers will grab the towel and twist them into the roller head. I managed to get the towel out, but it was tedious.<br /><br />Here is my regimen (repeated only once a month wooo!): Take 2 ibuprofen before I get into the shower. Shower and spend a little extra time with wash cloth and HOT water on legs. Rub them vigorously. Get out and dry.<br /><br />The cord is nice and long on this unit so I put one leg on the toilet lid. I do the shins first while they are still hot, but dry. Then my calves. I wipe off all the pulled out hairs and douse my legs with witch hazel. Using this, I have never gotten a &#34;after epilator&#34; burn or ingrown hairs with this. It cools and numbs and is also anti septic.<br /><br />I would highly recommend witch hazel after epilating.<br /><br />Comment here if you would like any other tips.<br /><br />My Favs about Epilator:<br />*1 time per month<br />*Less time than rasors<br />*No more buying disposables or cream<br />*Hair gets finer and finer every regrowth (just like waxing)<br />*The corded kind will never loose charge

  262. It's great item for removing hairs! It's was painful at the first time but then as i'm using it often, I feel less pain now Much better and simple then waxing!

  270. Maybe it's not the actual product's fault; just my skin..But regardless, I returned it because it kept giving me stubbly legs..I grew out my leg hair so it would work properly but it didn't leave smooth skin like the other reviews said. Instead I really wanted to go and shave because my legs felt so prickly.I exfoliated my legs every day and tried again after a few weeks but it still gave me stubbly legs. I'm guessing I'm very prone to ingrown hair and epilators are just not for me so back to Amazon it went. Surprisingly they accepted it even though it was used..<br /><br />Very jealous of people who can use epilators but I guess it's back to razors for me.
  271. I've been sick of shaving for months now and I've never wanted to try waxing because the pain and I have sensitive skin. I was looking up epilating and wanted to try this one out because of the reviews. I made a great choice. Yes, it does hurt in the beginning and yes, it is frustrating, but the results are amazing.<br />I've made a few reminders for myself and wanted to share with all of the new epilator users: 1. Remember to go slow! I know you want to get it all done, but seeing how you (and your skin reacts) to the first little introduction is crucial. Start with a small patch of hair, if you like it continue, if not stop and give yourself a few minute break and start again. 2. Keep the skin taut. This helps with getting the hair by the root out and can be less painful than if you didn't do this. After awhile, on my calves, I didn't have to keep it taut because it wasn't as painful (granted it took 3 or 4 tries, but it does hurt less!) 3. If you get ingrown hairs after, it's okay! I've gotten quite a few after doing my full lower leg, and it did frustrate me to no end because it looked noticeable (to me, anyway) that I had missed a few. You didn't, it's okay, breathe and just let the hairs grow back by themselves. 4. Sometimes it doesn't get the tiny stubbly hairs, so you'll need to let it grow out some. I'm still learning which is a good length, but experiment from time to time. Too long is more painful and too tiny doesn't do anything.<br />I haven't tried my underarms or other areas yet (too afraid with how painful those would be) and I just started my thighs. Granted, I'm doing small patches at a time because the hair there isn't as dark as my calves (in some areas, anyway), but the pain isn't as bad once you get used to it.<br />If you need to, shave some parts of your legs, wait a few days and then epilate. That helps if you want to try a new area (like the underarms, thighs, etc) because you're just pulling out the root and a little of extra hair which makes you feel less pain.<br />Also, I know a lot of professionals have said that this epilator doesn't get some hairs, while that is true, I've noticed since my hair grows in many directions, that you need to keep the epilator at a 90 degree angle on your leg and just follow the way the hair grows. It's not that hard to do once you do it a few times, and if you have to go 4-7 times over it, what's the big deal? Yeah, sometimes I did get frustrated, but I just remembered the results I got and kept going, no matter how long it took me to finish.
  272. This product is almost painless when I use it on my legs. However, it does not pull out some of the fine hairs, but it does clear the most of it. The long cable is really helpful for my case.
  273. Works fine. Similar to the older I have. I like it.
  274. Ok, so it hurt like HECK the first time I used it. I managed to get both legs done but there was no way I could do my underarms. Right after using it, my legs had red bumps from irritation (ie don't do it right before you go out!).<br /><br />I was surprised my legs didn't feel as smooth as if they had just been shaved. On close inspection, I realised it missed maybe half the hairs. After using it for 3 months, I still feel like it misses a lot of hair. I end up having to use it once a week but still have stubbly areas. Probably because some hairs grow slower? Plus, and this is not aimed at the actual epilator, but the process itself - you have to have stubbly legs in order to use it. Ew! Also, it breaks some hairs at the skin rather than pulling them out. The bikini area was ridiculously painful and it is easier to use tweezers to pull each hair one by one (although insanely time-consuming).<br /><br />All in all, I'm not feeling that it's a good substitute for shaving. My legs are never hair-free because it either misses some, breaks some hairs off at the skin, or the hair is too short.

With epilators, you have to bear the initial pain until your hairs adapt to the process... then it becomes easy... more of a tingling sensation.<br /><br />Alas, my poor Satinelle gave out on me recently, but 20 years was a good run.   333. I previously had a small epilator that ran on batteries and wanted a bigger one that was also rechargeable or could be plugged in. I only use an epilator on my underarms. That is really the only place I hate shaving. This one is fantastic! The cord is decently long and I love the 2 different speeds. I do not use the efficiency cap. I don't think I would get all of the hairs using that. The head is removable so you can wash it which is a huge plus. My old one did not have that option. I have seen recommendations that you should first shower to clean and warm up the area before using an epilator. I never do that. Actually, I tried that because my last one said to do that and it was awful!! It hurt, caused ingrown hairs and didn't remove all of the hair. I always use this at the end of the night before getting in the shower. It works extremely well. I haven't had a problem since doing it that way. I do immediately get in the shower after and wash the area well. Since I am not new to epilators, I knew it would be slightly painful. Yes, it hurts. Over time you get used to it and it doesn't hurt nearly as bad. The longer the hair is, the more it hurts too. I always try to use it while my hair is still short, but long enough for it to grab the hairs.

  336. GET RID OF ALL THE HAIR! BWA HA HA HA! Ok so really now. This thing works quite well on hair that has some length to it. Peach fuzz or random short strays, ehhh not so much. I find it does it's job excellently. It is an electric tweezer and as such pulls longer hairs out rather easily. Short hairs I'd recommend shaving afterwards or simply tweezing them by hand. More work you say? Probably. But longer results as well. Bear in mind you may see hairs still within a few days but those aren't the hairs you just pulled; those are the peach fuzz hairs you couldn't grab before with it. So after a few epilations It will keep a smooth appearance much longer. I do recommend combining it with shaving though if you want it to always keep a smooth feel too. That doesn't mean shave every day, but if you know your going to get down and dirty, epilate a day or two before, and then shave the day before or on the day (if you really wanted to).

  343. Had this for a couple of months now. I have dark course hair and sometimes two growing from one follicle. The first 2-4 times hurt like crazy. I'm sure because of quantity of hair and coarseness of it. Using Aloe after it during those first few times really helps. After that first rough week, it's been much better. It still stings a little but I've definitely gotten used to it. Plus, there has definitely been less regrowth for me so there's not as much hair to rip out and, it seems to me, the regrowth I do have is softer. I was shaving every single day and, no matter what, could always feel stubble in certain areas. While I still have to shave 1-2 times/week, it is significantly less than every single day and smooth as satin for 2-3 days. Exfoliating on a regular basis makes all the difference (2-3 times/week; I use coconut oil and sugar). Overall, from someone who could shave twice a day and still have stubble, I love epilating because at least when I'm done it's extremely smooth and, visually, no dark spots all over my legs from the hair still left in the follicle. Cord length on this model is awesome. It's pretty loud but seems to be decent quality.

  347. Ok, it's not perfect. No, you don't get that perfect &#34;I just shaved&#34; as smoothness that makes you want to run your hands over your skin every time. But I have extremely sensitive skin, and no matter how many times I used a brand new blade, exfoliated, shaved with the grain, used sensitive skin shaving gel and deodorant, treated my post-shave skin with everything I was told to use, and whatever other advice I came across, I always had embarrassingly bad razor burn on my under arms. I would go as long as I thought I could get away with going before shaving, but it didn't really help. Until this nifty thing. So I read the reviews, decided to ignore the &#34;legs only&#34; suggestion, and what a difference it has made. Razors would irritate my underarm so much that it would sting to put on deoderant. I've only had this for a few weeks, so the irritation is still going down, but it has made such a change for me.<br /><br />As others have said, try to pull the skin taut. If you have trouble with the pain, you can try kind of bouncing it, always being sure to keep it perpendicular to your skin, that way you're not getting too much pain in one area at a time. So, do a quick section, pick it up, do a section elsewhere, and so on. It may not be the most efficient method, but I was able to brave getting even around my bikini line in this way (obviously another sensitive area). For my legs, I still prefer the smooth feel of shaving, but I do get less irritation when I use this. Also, I'm much faster at shaving. So far, I've just been alternating and kind of doing whatever works out, which allows me to avoid shaving tricky areas like knees and ankles (where I typically tend to nick myself).<br /><br />I should maybe also mention that I suffer from chronic migraines, so the pain was relatively very manageable in my case. Obviously it will vary between individuals.<br /><br />In summary: If you have high pain tolerance and are willing to experiment a bit, this is worth adding to your arsenal of hair removal products, especially if you have sensitive skin.

It removed every single piece of hair I ran it across!! Much less painful then waxing, almost feels like a bunch of little tingles everywhere.   359. When a female friend informed me that most women prefer their men without any chest or abdomen hair, I was both shocked and a tiny bit offended. I don't know if it's true, but I don't really like being so hairy anyway, so I went ahead and bought some Nair. The results were disastrous (no better than simply shaving), so I did a little homework and decided to try this device. Epilating sounded painful, and truth be told, it is. But it works, and the pain is almost exciting. After the first time, I only need a sweep maybe once a week or so to keep my torso almost completely hair-free. It almost encourages me to use the device regularly, as the longer you wait, the more it hurts (more hairs). Some hairs end up being cut rather than pulled, but most are definitely yanked clean out, as you can see the little follicle at the ends. Cleanup is a breeze: just remove the top and run it under hot, soapy water. I'm not sure if I'd use this if I was a woman, since the hairs have to be at least a certain length for this to grab it. It grabs some VERY short hairs, but tiny stubble would present a problem.
  360. Epillating is an adventure. This does exactly what it was intended to do, albeit somewhat loudly. It's efficient and while it doesn't alleviate the pain of pulling out your short and curlies, it is more efficient than plucking.

  368. I bought this to replace my ancient Emjoi, but I'm afraid it just isn't as good. It really doesn't get all those thick dark hairs like I was hoping it would. It tends to break a lot of the hairs off instead of ripping them out from the roots. This is bad, especially if you're prone to ingrown hairs and cysts. I ended up with a nasty cyst after using this in the private area. This never happened with my Emjoi. If you haven't used an epilator before, just know that it hurts like hell, but, with the right one, it's totally worth it. I use mine all over, from the face (light peach fuzz above the lip and on the chin), underarms, and all the way down to the private bits. If you do it right, you can get a Brazilian thing going. That's IF you can handle the pain. Just make sure you wash the area you're using this on beforehand. I use Witch Hazel afterward to soothe the area.<br /><br />Not to be gross, but if you use this in your butt crack, make sure you ALWAYS keep it (the machine AND your butt crack) clean and dry or you could end up with a nasty cyst. If that happens, and you don't want to go to a doctor to have it lanced, apply Apple Cider Vinegar to a cotton round and leave it on there. Make sure you change this out a couple times a day until it's gone. Okay, TMI, but I can guarantee this WILL happen to some of you. It's best to have a plan of action before happens.<br /><br />Good Luck!
  369. I started epilating using the Braun Silk-Epil (series 5?), and this Philips one cannot compare.<br /><br />The Philips epilator is much more lightweight (in a cheapish way), has no light so you can see your skin clearly, has fewer and longer blades, and just covers less area in the same amount of time. It takes me probably twice as long to do my legs with this thing as compared to the Braun.<br /><br />Specifically, the Braun Silk-Epil I used had 40 tweezers. This one has half as many. I find myself going over the same area a couple of times whereas the Braun was a once-over sort of thing.<br /><br />Less important: the Braun came with a carrying pouch, a little cleaning brush, and three different swappable heads. The cord on the Braun is MUCH longer. The feel of the unit in your hand is also better with the Braun, which is a little rounder.<br /><br />The Braun was purchased for about $30 more, so this Philips unit is still a good deal. Still, we're doing this out of convenience, right? Next time I'd just make the splurge on the Braun unit.

  378. I guess I shouldn't give a product low stars based off the physical pain I experienced, something the product warns about, but I gotta give this a starred rating, in addition to this comment though I will talk about the performance.<br /><br />First things first: Holy cow, I must have really sensitive skin because there were moments when my skin actually bled. Not severely, just little dots of blood. Ok, so I dealt with that because it says it'll take some time to get used to. I also thought that maybe my hair needed to be longer, so I waited another two days to let that grow. I tried again, and the same thing! The epilator did pull hairs out, but missed a lot and also wouldn't pull them out at the roots on occasion, probably making the sensation more painful because it was just tugging on the hair and was failing to completely extract. So I'd have to repeat the motion to go back over and get missed hairs. There were also times I swore it was just pinching me and wasn't actually grabbing the hairs, but my skin. Perhaps that was just an assumption because it was stinging so bad, but my skin was so red and bumpy afterwards that I couldn't help but wonder.<br /><br />I also wanted to try it out on my boyfriend's hairy legs, because his hair was longer and easier to work with. It grabbed all the hairs! It was smooth on the small patch I used it on and he even said it wasn't hurting that bad, so maybe hair length is a major variable. I also don't want to wait until my leg hair is as long as his just to see if it works better. No one would appreciate that look! In addition to grabbing his hairs completely, it did leave his skin red and slightly bumpy the next day, which I was surprised about because his skin is a lot more durable than mine.<br /><br />So in a nutshell, the product DOES work but misses a lot of hairs, so motions and areas will have to be repeated and hit up again. Also, if you have really sensitive skin, I would imagine this things pain it displays isn't worth the hassle or the outcomes. On an objective note, everyone is different. People have different skin, pain tolerance, and product experiences. So don't take my comment as a determining factor. Just add it to your list of considerations.orth the hassle or the outcomes. I use Tend Skin as directed and I have no issues with either the infected hair or ingrown hair. I've tried using it at different angles and different speeds. I've tried before showering, after showering, the day after showering and after vigorous exfoliation -- it just doesn't work like it's supposed to. It does pluck some hairs, but it's hard to tell just how many because it breaks all the other hairs, making it look like it did a good job. Keeping the blades clean is the key to good epilation.

The other one was battery operated and the batteries drained really quick. Anyways, these things are extremely painful so I recommend getting some lidocaine which can be found for cheap here on Amazon. It's best to forgo razors. I have ice pick scars from the acne and razor bumps they cause plus they give me discoloration. Really ugly marks. When I shave the back of my neck with a blade, I get the same blotches that occur facially but leaving it alone for a month or two, using a good skin lightening soap like Kojie San, and going to the barbers and discontinuing using a razor to get my hair shaped up, helps me maintain a clear neck without ugly dark spots so I am assuming the same for my face. If you are a male with acne and bad hyper pigmentation (blemishes) and wonder why it's not clearing up, your razor is the issue and you should switch to one of these. It really does not matter if it's a version for females or male. This one looks unisex and it was cheap.   448. I've always had salon treatments to remove unwanted facial and underam hair (threading, waxing) but always used a razor for my legs. I got this Epilator hoping that I would cut my cost with all those treatments. I was pleasantly surprised that this Epilator worked well with my underarms and not too well on my legs, considering that the box says that it is for use for the LEGS.<br /><br />I can only conclude that the reason for easier epilating on my underarms is because the hairs there are used to regular plucking (by way of threading or waxing) and my leg hairs are not. I applied baby powder before using the epilator and made sure the skin was stretched and taut. The pain is manageable but expect more pain in (again) the areas which are not used to regular plucking.<br /><br />I highly recommend this epilator for those who are regulars at waxing and threading. I got my Epilator for 29 dollars and, compared with waxing costs, I expect it to pay for itself after 4 uses. I only gave it 4 stars because it's not as effective on all areas.

  450. Pros:<br />-Go a weeks between hair removal sessions. I epilated my armpits like a week ago and they look the same as the day I did them.<br />-When your hair does grow back, it's only a few hairs at a time and they are very light and fine so you hardly notice (unlike with shaving, when you definitely notice when it starts to grow back)<br />-None of that five o'clock shadow nonsense. Like with shaving how there's still hair under the skin that you can't reach and it's all dark and stupid looking and no matter how much you drag a razor over it, it's still there. Not so with the epilator!<br />-No stubble when the hair does grow back. No stubble ever.<br /><br />Cons:<br />-It hurts the first time you use it (just use a numbing cream if you want)<br /><br />My experience:<br />I considered getting a numbing cream because I didn't know what to expect. I'd never waxed anything other than my eyebrows, and those don't hurt me at all but I had a feeling the epilator wouldn't be so forgiving. Even the name sounds ominous. But I'm cheap and I was on a &#34;beauty is pain and I'm willing to endure it&#34; kick, so I ended up not buying the numbing cream and just powering through it with my left armpit. That hurt. So I kept shaving my right armpit for a few weeks. Eventually I bit the bullet and finished the right armpit. Again, it hurt. But I think I've built up a mental tolerance to the pain so it didn't hurt as much. Kinda just powered through it again. I still recommend a numbing cream.<br /><br />Silver lining:<br />After the first sessions, your hair grows back all nice and fine, so it doesn't hurt me anymore AT ALL. Seriously, it's like night and day. I'm blown away. My logic is that when the hair is course, you're pulling a thicker thing out of the pore. But when it's all fine, it's like pulling a regular head hair out of your head. I dunno. It doesn't hurt anymore and that's all I care about.<br /><br />Compared to shaving:<br />The epilator took about a minute topsand I could do it at 3am if I wanted. Whereas shaving is just a pain in the butt to me. I'd have to be in the shower (don't have time to get in the shower just to shave my armpits) or get my armpit all damp, shaving gives me cuts, and I have to unclog the razor with water every so often. Big hassle in my opinion.

But, I think the results will be worth it, since it seems to get less painful over time (I've had it less than a week and used it on my legs three times already, since I couldn't deal with the pain of doing it all at once) and since everyone says the hair grows back thinner or sometimes not at all.   470. Decent product for the price. The product comes with a guard which I tried to use at first but it kept me from removing the hairs and if you want to try to get all the hair to be removed its easier to just not have it attached, I know I was skeptical using without the guard because i feared that it would pinch my skin, but it doesn't do that. It does take a couple of tries to get all the hair ( not to mention its hard to get used to it pulling out the hair) and can cause irritation to the area for the first few uses. I just try to go over the hair slowly and try not to go over an area too many times - this will also cause some minor irritation.<br /><br />Id also say that it works better if the hair is trimmed down and is not over at least 1/4 inch long. I noticed while using the product that if the hair is longer it will just pull the hair without removing it, or just break the hairs without removing the root, regardless - it is quite painful.<br /><br />I have used this product on all parts of the body, legs, arms, and even sensitive skin (like underarm and bikini line) and it works just great, NOTE that it is very painful though and i would suggest for the sensitive areas to use a form of aftershave gel (my personal favorite is Bikini Zones aftershave GEL) and apply to the area to soothe irritation after using the epilator. Yes it does hurt, no matter where you use it (i mean, it is plucking hair out), its just a matter of getting used to. Try taking a warm/hot shower before using to make your pores open up a little more for a easier removal (make sure you are dry first though because this product is not water resistant).

  473. Since we are in the time where pubic hair is unwanted, we have to decide what method we want to use to keep our naughty bits smooth. The way I see it there are four options: Shaving (cheap and quick but stubble and ingrown hairs), depilatory creams (only moderately effective and can cause chemical burns to sensitive areas), waxing (various types with painful but effective results - works best with someone else doing the \\"ripping\\") and epilators.<br /><br />No one would say this isn't painful, to some extent, but it can be effective. I find that the pain is fairly easy to deal with, btu I do have to be careful to stretch the skin well with one hand while managing the epilator with the other. Still, there have been some pinches of my wrinkled skin (if you know what I mean!) that bled a little.<br /><br />I cannot compare the effectiveness of this particular device to other devices, because this is the only one I've ever used. I can say that it wasn't THAT painful and that I was pleased with the results. For areas that self-waxing is too difficult, this zips over and plucks everything out! If I were a woman, or were to convince my wife to use it, I think she would have better results with this than with waxing. I'll append this review if I can ever get her to try it!<br /><br />Update: Its been a few months since I first used this, and after the initial period of returning to my nether region to de-pube it, I \\"let things go\\" for a while. Got it out yesterday and started to do another \\"balding of the boys.\\" WOW! Did I mention how much this hurt, the first time? Maybe I was excited at the outcome enough the first time, to endure the necessary pain until the nerves got numb, but this time I gave up after less than three minutes! One thing to keep in mind is that waxing and ALL of these hair-pluckers say you should trim your hairs way down to 1/8\\" or so before using it. That keeps the \\"area of plucking\\" smaller and pulls the hairs straight out, rather than yanking clumps of hairs from halfway across your testicular sack. I paid the price in pain for not pre-trimming. What I neglected to mention when I first reviewed this thing is that when you start with it, it hurts like tiny demons stabbing your nether region. After about five minutes of use, though, I guess enough endorphins are released and the skin in the area becomes desensitized enough that it's not so bad.<br /><br />BTW, I liked my initial results so much I proudly showed it off to my wife and offered for her to use it. She isn't as excited by the \\"smooth\\" as I am, which means that _I_ get to be smooth while waiting on her to try it out. Seeing as she has had two children by C-section and two abdominal surgeries she ought to be able to deal with the initial pain easily, right?f hairs from halfway across your testicular sack. This didn't surprise me though, I was expecting it. But as the hair started to grow back (which it did in about 3 days, similar to shaving) parts of t grew back thinner but the rest grew back in grown. The in growns were painful as well. When my legs would get goosebumps, the ingrowns would feel horribly irritated as they tried to poke through the skin. I had to wait at least a week and a half before I could get all the ingrowns out. I did this through deep exfoliation and I had to shave twice within that time frame.<br />I tried it a second time hoping for better results but it was the same deal.<br />Both times I did everything I was advised to do to avoid ingrowns.<br />If you're prone to ingrowns when you shave, you'll probably get in growns (but worse) from this as well.
  499. So this is actually my second purchase of this epilator. I bought it a year ago and dropped it too many times when using it so it broke :(. But that was my fault! Darn butter fingers! All in all its a great epilator and you cant beat the price, so I bought it again. As far as epilation goes, I didn't like using it on my calves. In my opinion it hurt really bad in that area, but I do use it on my thighs. I also use it for upper lip hair, underarms, arms, lower back and belly area. When I first started epilating, it hurt like a MothaF. BUT, it gets less painful with time. Don't let that scare you away though. In all honesty, you just have to get through the pain the first time and you will be fine. If there is an area of your body that you just can't handle epilating(for me, my calves! ouch.), then definitely do not force it. Continue shaving or waxing there like usual. If you take a warm bath and use this afterwards, it shouldn't hurt too bad. Also! a lot of people think that its similar to waxing because the they both pluck the hair from the root, but thats not necessarily true. Waxing removes a section of hair all at once, whereas an epilator removes the hair one at a time from the root at a fast speed. So, basically waxing is painful, but quicker and epilating is a slower process in order to remove all of the hair in the area. Works like a charm and you cant beat the price! Hope this helped some of you make a decision :)
  500. I do not recommend this product to anyone. It's painful and barely removes hair.
  501. This epilator works great. I've never used one before, so I didn't really know what to expect. It hurts at first, but then I just got excited that I wouldn't have to shave every other day, and no more pain. It's really not bad. I did notice some redness and broken hairs after I was done, but I chalk this up to my inexperience in using the device. It's been about a week since I used it, and my legs are still mostly smooth...I need to go back and get those broken hairs... This was a great purchase. I'm very happy.

I've done a few, no ingrown hairs, but I also seem to have a problem with it grabbing all of the hair, I end up needing to go over several times and even then I may not have gotten it all. It does yank that sucker out all the way to the root, I mean do you realize how long your hair is under the surface of your skin? I skipped two days shaving and the hair I was getting looked like I had gone a whole winter. I also use this daily. I ran out of this for a few days and noticed a little irritation.
