  529. I'm pretty satisfied with my purchase. The package came in on time and with all contents in present. Since the instructions and most reviewers recommended, I took a quick warm shower and also exfoliated my legs to open up the pores and remove any dead skin so that my leg hairs would be easier to tweeze.<br /><br />Everyone has different types of hair and I happen to have semi-fine, straight black hairs (medium dispersal) on my legs. I also think (or at least I like to think) that I have a pretty high tolerance to pain. Because of these factors, I didn't feel any pain when epilating. It actually kinda tickled.<br /><br />I gave this product four stars because, after having this product for about a month now, I noticed that you have to wait for leg hairs to grow a certain length before you can epilate again because if its too short the tweezers on the epilator often times won't be able to grasp the shorter hairs. My hair starts to have some growth about 1 1/2-2 weeks after waxing/epilating. Other than that, it gets the job done pretty well.<br /><br />Also, word of advice, make sure to go slowly (or at least not as fast as I usually go) when epilating in order for the tweezers to firmly grasp your hairs and pull from the root. I've been going too fast and the hairs just end up breaking and I would have to go back again and do the area again. So, go slowly, one area at a time. Also, exfoliate everyday- otherwise you might have more ingrown hairs. And nobody wants ingrown hairs.<br /><br />All in all, I'd recommend this to anyone who doesn't want to spend as much time and money on waxing, and for people who are afraid of getting the rough stubble from shaving. Just be patient when epilating and remember to exfoliate. :)<br /><br />Side note: I've only sugar waxed my legs and I've never shaved them.

  590. I having been using this for about a month. I had not used an epilator since the original epilady in the early '90s. Thus is a huge improvement over that torture device. But, while to stay smooth I have to shave daily, with this, it is just weekly and the subsequent uses have gone much faster.   592. This really does remove unwanted hair. I have noticed when the hair grows back it's less and finer. Just be prepared for the pain.
  593. Day 1: First of all, I would like to point out that the photo of the woman using the epilator as if it is a cordless tool is misleading. This particular model must be plugged in for usage. This is my very first epilator. In the past, I would either shave or tweeze the hairs on my leg one strand at a time, which not only took forever, but for some reason, seemed to hurt more. I initially ran the epilator on my arms, and oh my goodness, I wasn’t quite prepared for the pain, as I was used to running an electric shaver on my arms during the summertime, and that was absolutely painless. I do, however, have an extremely high threshold for pain, so I quickly got over the initial shock of the painful feeling of having every strand of hair pulled out of my arms. Next came my legs, and again, the initial pain takes getting used to. Also, you do have to go over each section more than once in order to remove all the hairs. But 20 minutes later and tingling throughout my hand, my arms and legs are smoother than they would be after a shave! Note: If you are trying the epilator for the first time, it is best to try it over the winter season when shaving your legs isn’t a must!<br /><br />Day 2: One and a half weeks later, I started Round 2 of epilation. Oddly enough, I felt absolutely no pain at all. I do prefer epilation to shaving my arms and legs, as it leaves my skin much smoother and I don’t feel a 5 o’clock shadow coming back to my legs.<br /><br />Summary: this particular epilator is awesome and inexpensive. It is a little inconvenient that you have to plug it in when in use, but the tweezer heads are good about gripping even the shorter finer hairs. The Phillips HP6401 is small enough to fit in the pam of my hand. I definitely recommend this product!
  594. After looking at the product reviews I was sure that this product would seem reasonable but just after a dozen or so uses it decided to stop working. I kept it in a drawer safe from any moisture and mis-handling but after plugging it in yesterday it just wouldn't turn on. I thought there may have been some hairs causing it to jam but after inspection the problem seemed to lie in the main compartment where the electrical systems are.<br /><br />I expected that a 30+ dollar product that even had a plug in power source would last for quiet a bit longer than just a few months.<br /><br />Not going to buy this product again, waste of money.

It will turn red for a bit from irritating your skin with the pulling but it goes away after an hour. The little bit of pain is totally tolerable though, if it only was actually pulling out the hair . The lack of efficiency makes it annoying. It would take 4 to 5 strokes just to get most of the fine hair, but it wouldn't get all of it. Coarse lower legs were a joke. After 10 minutes I managed to pull out only half of my hair in a little 3 inch long patch. It. Was. Ridiculous. All that stinging and it was just tugging the hair not pulling it out. I slammed it on my counter, grabbed some lotion and a razor, and had both legs smooth in 5 minutes. I would rather spend five minutes everyday for smooth legs than have to spend all day long every week to epilate. I don't have that kind of time to waste.<br /><br />This 40 day manufacturer return is ridiculous as well. Make sure if you send it back to use insured postage (an extra 5 bucks). I forgot to add insurance on it, and even though they recieved it, they refused to refund me because it had to be insured to be accepted. So now its back with me, now past the 40 days, un-returnable, and I'm stuck with the piece of crap.

  617. I first heard of epilators from a friend of mine who would rave about hers! After feeling how smooth her legs (and arms) were I decided I had to give it a try. I browsed online and saw that the price on this one was decent so I decided to give it a go. When the box arrived it was packaged nicely and had all necessary materials. I took it out and tried it right away.<br /><br /> MECHANICS:<br />You have to have it plugged in while using it, it isn't wireless which isn't too bad considering it has a very very long wire. How this works is that it is basically like a bunch of tweezers that rotate and squeeze together at the top to grab your hair and pull it out. The epilator has 2 speeds, the lower one for hard areas, such as your shins, and the higher one for softer ares, such as arm pits or thighs). Mechanically it functions well. This little machines is pretty noisy so be ready to crank up the volume on anything you may be listening to.<br /><br /> EFFECTIVENESS:<br />Before purchasing I was a bit worried about the pain but my friend told me it wasn't that bad but I will admit that at first it was a bit painful. However, now that I have had some practice and getting used to it, the pain really isn't noticeable. I do get some red, splotchy bumps on my legs afterwards but it's nothing that a bit of lotion and 10 min of letting it fade won't get rid of. Another common concern that I have heard of is ingrown hairs. I have noticed some more on my legs but I exfoliate with a puff in the shower and so far so good. I have taken to epilating my once every 2-2.5 weeks which is a major improvement from shaving every couple of days. It takes me about 10-20 min each time and I usually watch a tv show or something while I'm doing it. I also love the fact that I can't accidentally cut myself with this.<br /><br />Overall I think this was a good purchase and it looks like it will hold up for awhile so it is worth the money. It saves me time and injury, it is easily transportable,not dangerous for children, and it is very effective!

  654. This is my 2nd Philips Satinelle Epilator. The 1st one lasted me over 20 years! I think Philips was the 1st company to come out with Epilator units. (But I could be wrong) You are not going to have that smooth as silk feeling that you get with shaving when you first start using it. But over time the hair will be less & less & it will grow back in longer & longer periods of time. I hardly ever have to do my thighs now, maybe once every 3-4 months. But I'm still working on my calf (lower) legs more often - However-- that is because I've shaved my lower legs off & on thru the years. I really wish I hadn't have & my lower legs would be like my thighs, having hardly any hair at all coming in & when it does you can barely feel it or see it. I'm now committed to my lower legs and will not go back to shaving at all, (middle aged now & it's just not that important to me that they be silky-smooth all the time). Plus I know it won't take long for them to be as smooth as my thighs feel if I just stick with it & never shave again. I also use it in bikini area, YES it smarts, but just hold your skin taunt/tight & there again, the nice thing is it doesn't come back in like after shaving. The first few times you use it on your legs you will feel it, but after a few times you get used to it & it smarts less & less. (And it's not like unbearable pain or something, just smarts a tad) To get the best results wait for your hair to grow out quite a bit each time you use it. It does a better job at getting more hair. I see no need to spend a lot of money on an Epilator, from my research they all work the same way as far as the mechanism itself. I love my new Philips Epilator and would have given it 5 stars, but in the end it's still not like shaving, but then again it doesn't claim to be. It claims to remove hair over time which is what it does, it just takes time & diligence to achieve that goal. If you're tired of shaving, I say go for it! Also, and I can't stress this enough!! -- ifyou have a daughter get her started on this & make sure she never shaves - I so wish I would have never shaved when I was a teenager & had begun with an epilator. It's shaving that makes the hair come back so quickly & so coarse. Before you ever shave the hair's soft and an epilator would work perfectly for the rest of one's life. (BTW, not recommended for under arms, shaving still fits the bill there.)

I will never use a razor again!<br /><br />Now, a little more detail about epilating if you care to read: This is my second time ever using an epilator and I was seriously scared of the pain! Being a newbie, I started-out very slowly. It took me about 3 hours to do both legs beneath the knees. I hear from others that it gets easier and less painful the more you do it. Definitely do not use it like a razor like I did the first time. The first time I epilated, I pulled it slowly up my leg and OUCH!! If you want less pain, go little by little, back and forth, inch by inch. It also helped me to hold the skin taught where I was epilating - place your pointer finger and thumb and act as though you're trying to stretch the skin. It dulled the pain for me. For extra sensitive areas (such as the knees), I turned up the speed and moved the device back & forth faster. This reduced tugging on stubborn hairs and made it feel more like a quick tweezer pluck.

  665. I've never epilated before, and have only waxed my legs with those pre-waxed strips once or twice that always end up messy and irritating the skin more than pulling out any hair. i usually shave.<br /><br />My roommate in college had an epilator, and the thought of having smooth and non-hairy legs all the time was appealing in a college-setting, where I wore shorts around my room and would have random neighbors visit at all hours of the day and night. it would be nice to not have to quickly change into long sweat pants whenever we had a visitor. I had a 30$ giftcard to amazon, so my total cost for this ended up being 5$, which was great.<br /><br />When i received it I quickly tried it. I exfoliated my legs with a loufa. My leg hairs are somewhat fine, and they were about the ideal 3-4 mm length. I started the epilator on speed one, and was more scared by the sound than anything. I didn't use purple head-piece/cap thing. It was useless. I lightly touched the epilator to my skin and then forced my self to hold it and drag it across my skin. I was surprised at how painless it was. I don't wax or epilate normally, so it's not as if I became used to the pain. For me, if just felt as if someone was dragging a comb with sharp teeth across my skin (not to the point of pain, just a little irritation. It felt as if how you feel when you scratch dry skin--not painful perse, but kinda itchy and irritable). The skin around my knees was more sensitive. But even then, not so much pain as kind of irritation.<br /><br />As for the efficacy, it's hard to tell just from looking at my legs (my room lights are somewhat dim). most of the major visible hairs are gone off my legs. If i look at the white epilator itself, i can see the hairs that have come off. Many of them i can see the tips have the follicle/round black part on them, which mean that they have been successfully pulled off from the root. Some of the other ones look like they have been ripped/broken off. It's hard to say exactly what percentage of my hairs were ripped vs. pulled out successfully. Additionally, my legs still feel very very sightly stubbly since the tiniest of hairs did not come out.<br /><br />After i finished, i actually exfoliated my legs again with St. Ives apricot scrub, which is what I use on my face. I want to be sure that I don't get ingrown hairs, which would be another good way to measure the effectiveness of the epilator. I will wait and see, I suppose.<br /><br />I have yet to see the long term results, but I'm surprised at how well it worked compared to some of the reviews other people gave regarding pain and time (atleast for a first time user). I'd say it didn't take 10 minutes per leg for me, but maybe 5 (just to stop and see where hair is left on my leg). It is pretty loud, but i feel like most epilators will be loud. don't be intimidated by the sound. My skin also didn't get too red or bumpy either. I usually take care of my skin, so maybe that's why it wasn't so sensitive. Because I'm a first time user, it's possible that I didn't get the full extent of pain because i didn't hold it correctly, and I only used it on my legs. But given the circumstances, I'm happy with my $5 brand name epilator.

You may find it miss some hair the first or even second passing, sometimes changing the direction would help to eventually remove it. I found it very effective with even shorter hair.   681. This is my first epilator, and although it doesn't work quite as well as I had hoped, I'm still happy with my purchase. I still shave regularly (every other day or so), but this does help my legs get less scratchy between shaves. Most of the hair on my arms and legs is very fine and blonde, so with these hairs it tends to just break a lot of them instead of pulling them out. I find that it works a lot better on thicker hair (such as underarms or bikini area) and I've had better results with that. I have noticed a few ingrown hairs on my legs and I didn't have them before, but I'm prone to them on other parts of my body anyway so it doesn't surprise me. As far as pain goes, I think it depends a lot on where you plan to use it. On my arms, legs, and underarms it was way better than I expected--just a little stinging but nothing unmanageable. It hurts more on the face, the tummy, and especially the bikini area, but I'm getting used to it. Besides, if it hurts, that's how you know it's working! The cord is plenty long if you're worried about that, but it does tend to tangle easily, and sometimes when I'm using it flickers on and off because the part where the cord plugs into the unit is loose or something. And I threw away the cap because I sat on it and broke it (oops) but it doesn't do much anyway. Overall I'm pleased with my purchase, even if it isn't totally effective, and for the price compared to other epilators I think it does a good enough job.
  682. My hair grows back much more slowly and thinner now. This epilator works great and it's a plus that it's on the cheap end. I just wish epilators in general weren't so loud.

  689. I should start by saying I am a faired skinned Italian girl...nuff said. I have tried it all...electrolysis, waxing, laser hair removal, cream removers, cream dyes, shaving, plucking. Short of an upper lip, chin and jawline transplant I have done everything. The electrolysis I did years ago left my upper lip scarred but removed the black ones. Laser hair removal only killed the black hairs that had grown back but did nothing for the light hairs. After pregnancy I was left with long grey hairs of varying thicknesses as well as a few black ones under my chin and along my jawline. I tried all of the remedies above but never achieved smooth, hair-free results...UNTIL NOW.<br /><br />I pulled this baby out of the package, read through the instructions and went for it. Was I scared? You bet my hairy chin I was. I tried it first with the safety cap and started along my jawline. I was surprised that it didn't hurt more. Don't get me wrong, it was not like the hairs were being licked off by kittens. It felt like small rubber bands hitting my face. But as I moved along I could handle it pretty well. I got brave and removed the cap and upped the speed. I moved to under my bottom lip and it felt like the rubber bands were getting bigger. Then I took a deep breath and headed for the upper lip. Tears began to form and I saw a few stars so I had to stop. Once I came to (kidding), I soldiered on. I decided to lower the speed and go in short bursts for this area. Yeah, I made it through. Yeah, it hurt. You just have to decide if the pain is worth the price of beauty. I was a little red after but not bad. I am curious to see how long it takes for the hair to grow back in and if they are finer. I will try to update the review. For now, I am as happy as a baby's bottom...you know, smooth.<br /><br />If you on the fence, try it. You only have hair to loose.

  714. I've been using Emjoi epilators for 15 years. Their design and build quality has not changed (evolved) over the years. Emjoi is a decent product but the Philips is better. Better designed, the metal tweezers are machined to have closer tolerances resulting in a smother and more efficient (fewer passes) epilation. My bony knee caps were challenging with the Emjoi, requiring multiple passes. With the Philips I get the job done in a third of the time. The Philips has a 2 year warranty. Emjoi - 1 year.

  722. I have never used an epilator before. After tirelessly reading the reviews and researching the specs, I chose to purchase the Philips. The cost seemed reasonable (the more expensive ones just seemed to come with more attachments, which I didn't need), and the device was fairly straight-forward and seemed easy to use.<br /><br />I was very nervous about the pain when I first tried it out, but it turned out to be not too bad. It was painful - like little pricks or stings - but bearable. I had to go over my legs multiple times to get all the hair, and I still didn't get everything. I started on the first speed setting and after becoming more confident, moved to the second speed setting. I was definitely disappointed with the amount of hair removable - based on the other reviews, I thought it was going to remove everything.<br />Afterward, my legs were covered in little red bumps and my skin was really irritated (as I expected). I put some lotion on and by the next morning the skin looked normal again. I tried it each day for the next couple of days - I felt the epilator tugging at missed hairs but again, it didn't remove everything. I also couldn't tell if the epilator was actually removing the hair or just breaking it as it pulled. My legs over the next couple of days definitely did not seem as smooth as they would have been right after shaving.<br /><br />I'll probably continue to use this product, but I'm definitely disappointed with the hair removal.

This is what I had done, and now I just have to epilate every day for 5-10 minutes to remove the hair that is slowly growing in. I've had hairless legs, underarms, and most of my bikini line (this area in particular requires quite a bit of finesse) for the last three weeks and I could not be happier.<br /><br />My underarms certainly hurt quite a bit, but if you're used to the pain of waxing your upper thighs or your bikini line, you should be fine with the pain. The legs on the other hand were almost painless, and the results are better than I could have ever imagined. It takes some getting used to at first (but the learning curve is not steep), and once you realize to keep the skin tight and hold the epilator at a 90 degree angle, you've pretty much become a pro.<br /><br />As someone who struggled through shaving for six years, and waxing for four, this option is cheaper, more effective, and less invasive than anything I have used before. And as someone who gets ingrown hairs from waxing constantly, I find that as long as I dry exfoliate with a brush, I have hardly any ingrowns now! Never going back :)

If done correctly you can minimize the pain (tighten up the skin and only lightly contact it with the epilator), and hurts way less than waxing. If you've tried everything else like waxing, nair and shaving and you're sick of not removing all the hair then I would certainly give this a try.<br /><br />Hope it helps!

  760. I'm actually being lenient with this review on this product, mainly because I was not aware it was only intended for legs only by design, and I also did not know one needed to use these things shortly after a couple of days of exfoliation, and shortly after a shower to loosen the hairs.<br /><br />After a first use, I noticed quite a number of hairs did not come out, but were merely broken near the skin, leaving some stubble. Also noticed a lot of red bumps where thicker hairs were removed, or just pulled on, and broken instead of being removed.<br /><br />Where this product works best are areas where hair is thinner, at least that's the performance I noticed.<br /><br />I do wish I'd gotten the more expansive models which are intended for body hair, rather than just legs.<br /><br />I wish this thing had rechargeable batteries. The power cord is not quite long enough to use without some form of extension cord, even though the manual advises against using extension cords. Kind of lame, that.<br /><br />This was my first time epilating body hair. It is a bit painful, but if you're careful, and don't try to mow through too much, too quickly, it's not as bad as the youtube videos of guys freaking out at the first touch of these things appear. I'd describe the sensation as being like getting a zap from a doorknob on a cold winter day after walking across a carpet. Only it's happening a lot until the hairs are gone. If you just start by touching the skin a few times, and then slowly work your way through for a few seconds at a time, it's not as bad.<br /><br />I must say, the advantage of epilating over shaving is well worth the discomfort. Shaving results in a lot of irritation only a couple of days later. Epilating lasts much longer, with no irritation later.<br /><br />I'll definitely get a more expensive model later on.

  769. Received my purchase in really good time, and in good order. This is my first epilator, so was a tad nervous about using it after reading some of the reviews. I gave it a 4 star, because it would be perfect if it was battery operated, not reliant on a cord. Love the shape, easy to hold on to . Love the color and design. Very easy to assemble, use and clean. The instructions would be better for some if they had a picture showing angle placement they are describing (sometimes a lot of words get in the way of the visual). The &#34;pain&#34; was not horrific :D it is a shocker if your new at it, but it is more a slight/quick sting, then poof gone. I found that if I went in fast little spurts the initial sting was nothing, and after a few minutes your zipping along in your own little world. I'm very glad I purchased this, and will continue to use it regularly. Hope this helps!

  815. It's basically a motorized row of tweezers. You do have to hold it at the correct angle for it to work well, so read the instructions and practice using the included pink/purple snap on guide. If you don't learn to do it right, you will only break off hairs at the surface and end up with ingrown hairs.<br />I found that I have the best outcome if I use it right after a shower (exfoliate the area to prevent clogged follicles) and use either an antiseptic spray or astringent like sea breeze on the area immediately (and for the next couple days.) The antiseptic/astringent is very important! If you are prone to clogged pores or body acne, plucking all of that hair is going to leave a lot of places for bacteria, dirt and oil to gunk up. You will look like you are covered in zits! Using sea breeze will clear this up after a few days, though.
  816. This is the first epilator I've ever purchased and used, and after the initial horrifying experience of getting used to the way it feels, I'm overall pretty pleased with this product. Although it does have to be plugged into the wall, the cord is very long and I haven't had a problem finding a spot to use it in. As a first time user, I'm very pleased with the results. After about 20 mintues on each leg (at full growth) there is minimal regrowth after over two weeks, this coming from a person who usually has to shave every other day. The price is great compared to other models I've seen on Amazon and overall I'm happy with this purchase. I probably won't use it anywhere besides my legs because I can barely stand that pain, but it's perfect for people who hate shaving in the shower. The only downside is that I had some trouble cleaning it but overall I'm glad I purchased it.

This hair is not growing back much at all. In the past I have paid big bucks for facial waxes. The result was the same in all areas, smooth for a day or two, and then two weeks of intense itching and ingrow hairs. Yes, I exfoliated before and after.   863. I bought this because I was tired of shaving every other day just to keep my legs smooth, and this product works really well at keeping them smooth for much longer. Had to do it every three or four days at first due to hairs being in various stages of growth but once I'd gotten them on a bit of a schedule I can go for a week or more without it.<br /><br />Be prepared for some pain the first few uses though if you aren't used to having your hairs pulled out at the roots. The first time I used it I spent nearly five hours doing it because I had to keep stopping because of how badly it hurt. Figured it would be painful but wasn't quite prepared for just how much some of the more sensitive spots would hurt!<br /><br />It gets better though, once you get it on a schedule the hairs come in more fine and in less density making the experience much easier and less painful. If you have sensitive skin like I do you might want to do this on a weekend until your skin gets used to it as well, because I had some pretty bad redness and soreness the first time that lasted for the better part of a day. Really fun day at work the next day as my pants kept reminding me of it with every step! Took several uses for it to stop happening and a decent moisturizer can really help with it.
  864. I am so glad that I purchased this epilator. I only received it a few days ago and I already love it! As you probably guessed, it is not entirely pain free since it pulls the hair from the roots. However, I didn't find it to be too much to handle. If you aren't sure whether you can deal with the discomfort, try plucking a few hairs (with a tweezer) from the area where you plan on using the epilator. Using the machine is like plucking several hair at a time. Each stroke will not remove every hair; rather, you will need to go over the area a few times, which is personally how I would prefer it anyway.<br /><br />You can make the process easier on yourself by exfoliating the skin and taking a shower before using the epilatot. This will make the hair softer and reduce some of the discomfort. Afterwards, you may want to apply some aftershave or lotion. I wouldn't suggest anything highly scented though.<br /><br />The process is gentle on the skin and it's basically impossible to cut yourself. I accidentally went over an area where I already had a cut; the epilator did not cause any issue.<br /><br />The cord is nice and long, so you don't have to sit right next to an outlet.<br /><br />Bottom line: Great purchase!

  876. After years of shaving I decided to start sugaring instead. While I LOVED the results, it was tedious, messy, and awkward. I considered starting to make appointment for professional waxing again, but the cost per event was just not going to be feasible. When I remembered having an original Epilady many years ago, I wondered how it had been improved over the years. I searched reviews, watched videos on youtube, and settled on this model. Honestly, I spent a little over 2 hours using it the first time. (Visual Warning!) I have black, somewhat coarse/heavy leg hair. The hair on my legs was quite long and I wasn't sure what sort of disaster I was going to have on my hands, but this unit took care of it with no problem! I would equate the initial pain to being stung by wasps......many many angry wasps. But my determination took over and I continued, all the way up to my bikini line. Handy tip: Be VERY careful when using this anywhere near your pubic hair. Use your imagination, it's not a fun time. But again, once all was said and done I was sooooooo smooth and soooo satisfied with the results. I didn't have stubble 10 minutes later, in fact I didn't see anything worth removing for a week! Something I remembered from being waxed years ago is your hair has its own growth cycle. Once you start epilating, try to stay on a regular schedule. I DID have the typical ingrown hairs at first, but it was easy to deal with and had no pimples, boils, infections, etc. A good exfoliating glove helps tremendously, use it while you're in the shower before you use the epilator and it will help expose any hairs that may have started to grown under that thin top layer of skin. The pain factor is severely reduced from angry wasps to nothing more than some annoying skeeters that can't quite bite you. I am looking forward to wearing shorts this summer and I might be brave enough to wear them in public for the first time in my life! For what I would have paid for two professional waxings, I bought this epilator instead and in my opinion, from a 'hairy chick', it is well worth the investment.
  877. Works like a charm and removes hair with minimal pain!
  878. This was just what I needed to remove those errant hairs on my chin and neck. I did use it on my legs but it seemed to take longer than just shaving first then using this to supplement in between. Very affordable.
  879. Really happy with this epilator. My hair grows too fast and thick after shaving, so shaving my legs every other day is not an option for me ( who has time for that anyway?! ) Epilating keeps me hairless for at least a week and a half and not only that but my leg hairs are really fine and soft. This epilator might me small but it is mighty and pretty fast which is crucial for getting the job done. Plenty of little tweezers that rarely brake the hairs. My least favorite part is cleaning it, but If you want it to work properly every time you have to clean it at lest every 4 uses, but that applies to any other epilator on the market. Oh and if you wonder if it hurts, it does a little the first few times but you get used to it fast.

And you won't have to shave for at least a week at a time.<br />To those who've used an epilator before: if you are willing to be patient, the price is fair.   986. This is my first epilator. I wanted to get a cheap one just to see how I liked it. Unfortunately I wanted a full body one and didn't understand that this was only for legs, or at least that is what it says in the manual. Before using it I had uh.. a lot of growing out, then I shaved, then used this a few days later. It worked well, and didn't hurt nearly as much as I was fearing. I shortly took off the newb cover and turned it from speed 1 to speed 2. It did a good job of grabbing the hairs, and I didn't notice any breaking off. My second use wasn't as successful. With the hair grown back more sparsely and soft, it didn't really grab a lot of them as well and I did notice at least a few breaking off. I do agree with a comment that I remember reading when I was choosing to buy one(which was not necessarily about this model), which is that it never felt smooth like after shaving. Even though it looked smooth it felt bumpy, so I am not sure if it is actually pulling the hair out from as deep as it should. I still think it's worth using, especially at this price point, shaving to me always feels like a hassle and a waste of water. Eventually I'd like to try one with more power to it.

The 5 o'clock shadow is much better, as what he was seeing was hair under the skin. This thing frightens my cat a bit because it's noisy, but it grips hair well and isn't all that painful. I have to go over each area a few times for maximum effectiveness.<br /><br />I guess from seeing the picture, I thought that it would be charged and then used, but it has to remain plugged in while in use.   992. I use for bikini line/armpits. I've never epilated before and what everyone says about it hurting at first and then you going numb is absolutely true. Every time you do it, you kind of expect what it feels like at that point so it's not really so bad. I used it without the guard like the 3rd time I picked it up and got way better results. Gets rid of the hair well, but it definitely has to be a certain length (5/8 inch or something) and it's better when it's sticking straight up (I epilate when I'm cold lol). I gave 4/5 stars because my hair starts growing back sooner than I wanted to (2-3 weeks instead of a full 3 or 4), but that might just be my body. The device also misses a couple of hairs sometimes, but I'm a newbie and it just may not be the right length at a certain spot. I'd recommend - great price!

I did my &#34;test areas,&#34; but I couldn't resist the temptation to do more on my leg. The cord is super long so I don't have a problem reaching anywhere. After using this product I can normally go about 2 weeks without epilating again. Also, it takes a pretty long time to epilate my legs (probably about 20 mins) because this is not the most expensive product out there. But for $30-50 it is totally worth it to me! It's loud, and my husband asked what was happening, but it was quick and easy to do my feet and lower leg (right to my knees). But now, when some leg hairs started growing back, I decided to give it a second chance, instead of wrestling with that pot of gooey wax. Fox in Teen Wolf.<br /><br />I chose this particular model of epilator based upon the positive reviews and am now happy to add my own to the list. Keep in mind that my leg hairs were less dense than usual, due to the intermittent at-home waxing, so there was less to rip out. I would definitely recommend getting a wax first and then using this epilator once the hairs start growing back. There are few errant hairs remaining but overall it did a great job!   1096. Some of the other reviewers have already done a good job of outlining the general pros and cons of epilating versus other methods of hair removal, so I will keep my review brief. This is my first epilator after years of waxing, both at home and at salons. I don't know why it never occurred to me that this was still an option, but I'm really glad I tried it. This little gadget plugs in with a cord, is about the size of my palm, and gets my legs virtually hair free in about 5-8 minutes. Of course all other methods are a little less comfortable than straight up shaving, but the rough stubble and constant upkeep of shaving was something I outgrew in college. After probably at least ten years of waxing, I started seriously considering forking over money for electrolysis because I no longer wanted to make the time to complete the waxing process (heat the wax for an hour or more, perform the awkward waxing, clean all the drips and strings, etc) and paying $30-50 a month for waxing just wasn't financially reasonable anymore. This is a piece of cake. It is far less painful than waxing and doesn't bother me at all except a tiny bit on the back of my calves where I am sensitive. If it does feel uncomfortable, a little trick is to run it over the skin faster than recommended because it creates a kind of sensation that you really get used to and then can slow down and pluck more hairs without initial sting. I am really happy with this as a solution to the constant bother of waxing. It doesn't grab every single hair, but you could tweeze if necessary and I think the results are every bit as good as my usual waxing. I would definitely buy this again.
  1097. I have been very pleased with this epilator. For its price I get good coverage of hair removal, relatively quick results, few problems such as ingrown hairs, and (over weeks of use) less grow back. If considering, this is a good, inexpensive, handy epilator (for me).<br /><br />For more details, read below:<br />I am very ( :-( ) hairy for a woman. When I shave, though my legs are 95% smooth directly after, I will have noticable stubble within 12 hours. During the summer I regularly shave daily or every other. I have not had much experience (or luck) with waxing. However, just before getting this, I had been experimenting with sugar waxing. I have never had or used an epilator before.<br /><br />I have had the epilator for about 3 months now. I used it almost immediately and had legs about as smooth as if I had shaved. A few days later, though, my legs were ready for another go-round. For the first month, I probably used it 2-3 times a week. This I attribute to different growing cycles. While it catches the majority of the hair, any too short or too long will remain. I either shave, pluck, or wait a few more days for those hairs.<br /><br />I found it less painful than waxing and more like a quick sting (as others noted) on sensitive areas like behind my knees. I have had almost no ingrown hairs from this device. (Note: I did have ingrown hairs from the waxing, which I have been slowly working on. As I work those out the device has not noticeably created any new patches; just maybe one or two.)<br /><br />Since the first month I don't even use it once a week. My hair has grown back thinner and softer. Most areas grow back slowly and a few not at all. The plug in has not been an issue for me, as there is a long cord, and it's small enough to fit in my medicine cabinet.<br /><br />I am very pleased with this device and would definitely recommend it. I will probably some day move on to an epilator with more blades (?) and a wider path. This device can take time depending the area you're working on. I'm impatient and often have to go back to areas I missed. The removable head has been handy in making sure it is cleaned after every use (and therefore I've had no issues with sanity).
  1098. This epilator has been worth every penny. I had an Emjoi in the same price range before and this Satinelle epilator is a much better product. The key feature seems to be that the tweezing discs are flush against the skin which allows it to pull out hairs which are very short. This epilator does a very good job of pulling the entire hair out root and all. My last epilator would break many of the hairs and leave the root. I am a guy who works out a lot and body hair is just really uncomfortable so I use this product on my chest, back, and legs. The first time I used the epilator it hurt quite a bit but after using it for a few weeks I don't feel any pain at all. One thing that you should do with any epilator is to invest in a good exfoliating sponge/brush. I use an exfoliating sponge and brush every time I shower and this makes a huge difference with ingrown hairs. One other thing I am noticing with this epilator is that the hairs have already started to become finer and softer. That did not happen with my last epilator and I think this is due the entire hair being pulled out. Anyway, I am really happy with the Satinelle and I am buying another one to have as a backup.

  1114. I've had this since August, 2012. I got it mainly to reduce skin irritation that I got from shaving and to save a little money by not waxing. I've been using it regularly since then, it still works great, and it reduces skin irritation while saving me money. Here's the low-down: I'm assuming that if you're a person who has hair, you understand that yanking your hair out is not a pleasant experience. Is using this epilator more enjoyable after a glass of wine and NSAID of your choice, at least at first? Yes, but so are a lot of things in life, so I don't consider that a big mark against it. Furthermore, it starts hurting less and less the more you use it. I don't know if that's because my technique has improved or because my pain tolerance has, but either way, I no longer require the aforementioned glass of wine and NSAID. Doing my legs isn't my favorite sensation, but I would no longer characterize it as painful. My underarms are a bit more sensitive, but I can do them both in one sitting without any major discomfort. Beyond that, this thing does the job without irritating my skin. I threw out the guard I got with it within a month because it just isn't necessary, but it was nice at first because I was a little leery of it pinching me (it doesn't pinch, by the way. That was me being silly). I can do my legs and underarms in 20 minutes flat, and they stay smooth for a week. The epilator itself has never shown signs of breaking, slowing down, or becoming less effective. I do keep a pack of razors on hand for emergencies when I just don't have time to epilate, but I've used one pack in the past year and a half. I haven't had issues with ingrown hairs with this--if anything, I have far fewer ingrown hairs than when I shaved regularly. It does take a while to get all of your hair growing on the same schedule. I live in Florida and wear a lot of skirts, so if there's a special occasion coming up, I'll epilate or shave what stubble I have, which means I'll be yanking some hairs out when I epilate next and leaving others, but even with my lack of commitment I only have to epilate every week at the most. I've been going a week and a half without looking unduly stubbly, lately, and I'm hoping to be able to go two weeks before too very long. I've noticed the areas I regularly epilate seem to have slowly lost some hair, and the hair that remains is finer and lighter. I am very pale (despite living in Florida) and have dark body hair, so this development is a huge relief and lets me go longer between epilating. As to getting this thing to work maximally well, here are my tips: +Hold the epilator in one hand and hold the skin tight in the other. No, hold the skin tighter. Tighter! Like you mean it! Does it hurt to epilate? Yes? You're probably not holding the skin tight enough. +Take some NSAIDs and/or glass of wine the first few times. Do the epilating in patches--this gives you time to relax and troubleshoot your technique. +Technique is important and you will get better with time. This is a skill and is frustrating at first, just like shaving your legs was (I mean, I still can't shave my legs without nicking the back of my ankle or my knee). Give it a few tries before giving up. +Legs are the least painful areas to epilate, at least for me, followed by underarms. Bikini line is doable, but legitimately painful. I tend to get ingrowns there even if I epilate, so I've just cut my losses and opted for swim shorts. As I said, this product has led to less skin irritation, saved me money, and is still working after a year and a half. It costs less than getting your legs waxed and it does the job just as well with a little practice. I recommend it! ETA: I've had this product for two years and counting. I can go for two weeks (more, if I'm not wearing skirts every day) between epilating my legs or underarms, and I have reached the level of epilating expertise where I can domy bikini line with only a little discomfort. As I said, it takes skill, which takes practice, and also persistence. This gadget costs less than a single leg wax, has lasted two years, and is still going strong. Does it hurt a little at first? Yep. So does waxing (or shaving, if you're clumsy like me and accidentally cut your knees or ankles). Does it work, get easier/less painful with time, and last a while? Absolutely! I have and continue to recommend this product very highly!
  1115. I actually didn't buy this off of amazon, I snagged it at the Meijer down the street from my house on clearance at $27.99! I didn't think I'd be getting much considering they had to mark it down, so I was pretty much ready to try it, return it, and never talk about this experience again.<br />A little backstory:<br />I, like probably every other woman, have been on the hunt for a hair removal method that actually works, and keeps the hair away for a long time. Unfortunately for me, I have super sensitive skin, and can most certainly cannot afford the laser hair removal! (Who can!) I clearly wouldn't recommend anything with Nair, but that was only my personal experience.<br />After the Creams were effectively a bust, I saw the Philips Satinelle Epilator at my local Meijer, I cringed the first few times I saw it, because the picture described that it would be ripping out the hair by the root, like waxing! But I am a big wuss when it comes to pain, I do have a couple tattoos as well, but after a few days of thinking, I decided, &#34;what the hell. I can return it if it doesn't work.&#34; I bought it.<br /><br />It hurts, yes. But your ripping out the hair by the root! What do you expect? I was going to dinner with my Aunt and cousins, so I only had time to do one leg before I left, which I felt would be a good trial run. It wasn't too bad, but if it gets too bad, all it takes for relief is to lift the epilator away. After the initial epilation of my right leg, there were some bumps, and was a little rough, but by the time I returned the bumps had gone away, and my legs were super smooth! my tattoos haven't looked this good since I got them done! I put on some lotion, and my leg looked great! Awesome! I went to do my left leg, and it hurt quite a bit more. I think it could be because I'm right side dominant but it got done. After some point, the burn/itch became almost therapeutic!<br /><br />No bumps, no irritation, no redness, almost no hair! I'm sure after a couple uses, I'm sure I'll perfect the usage of this!<br /><br />Another thing I probably should have mentioned earlier, exfoliation is a MUST. I would highly recommend taking a hot shower before epilating, and exfoliating while taking said hot shower. It'll keep the ingrown hairs to a minimum. I would also suggest exfoliating regularly, it'll not only keep your legs super smooth, but it'll also keep the ingrown hairs down.

  1152. About me:<br />No tattoos, never had a baby<br />Have waxed my legs before<br />My leg hair is jet black and my skin is pale. I needed a hair removal system that would last longer than shaving but not be too expensive.<br />Absolutely hate shaving; I was ready to shell out a lot of money on laser hair removal<br /><br />Why I chose epilation: Epilation is the only FDA approved method for permanent hair reduction. This means if you epilate regularly for long enough, you may see a reduction in the number of hairs. I have been using this epilator for over six months and it does seem I have fewer hairs in the areas I regularly epilate. But that is just anecdotal evidence, so you may want to do your own research if you are looking for permanent hair removal.<br /><br />Why I chose epilation over waxing: less mess and lower cost. The epilator doesn't have wax I need to dispose of and I don't need to keep purchasing wax and strips.<br /><br />Why I chose epilation over shaving: epilation lasts longer and doesn't cut my skin like razors. I haven't had razor burn since I started epilating!<br /><br />So, why this epilator? My friend uses this epilator and the reviews seemed encouraging. I am very happy with this purchase. It is easy to clean, easy to use, and very effective. The two speeds are really nice; I use the fast setting on my legs and the slow setting on my armpits.<br /><br />Helpful advice so you can learn from my mistakes:<br />Absolutely do not use this on your face. I tried using it around my eyebrows and severely hurt the skin where I used it. There was a bad rash that lasted several days. I had read the instructions saying not to use it on your face, but I did it anyway. I feel very dumb for having done this.<br /><br />Be careful if you use this on your underarms. The first few times I epilated my armpits they became very irritated but this only lasted overnight. I could use deodorant in the morning just fine. Now when I epilate my underarms, I only use the slower setting and only go over the area once or twice. I haven't had a problem with irritation since starting these two practices. Also, the first time I epilated my armpits hurt so much tears poured out of my eyes. It still hurts more than my legs, but not as badly as when I first epilated them.<br /><br />Epilating the bikini area hurts so much. It hurt terribly the first time and the pain has only lessened slightly. I feel each hair and the pain is very intense.<br /><br />Hopefully this incredibly loquacious review has helped you make an informed decision!slower setting and only go over the area once or twice.   1160. If you have a grumpy pants man in your life this is the perfect thing to get him back into shape! When he comes home grumpy from work, whip this thing out and turn it on.. He will instantly turn his frown upside down and then offer to give you a back massage!!<br /><br />Honestly, though.. this thing hurts but the pain is totally worth it! Your legs come out soft after a few hours!<br /><br />Being a woman with dark, thick leg hairs is quite embarrassing. I shave and have stubble a few hours later! So when I was bored the other night browsing Amazon, I came across an &#34;epilator&#34;. I had never heard of this fancy machine before. I have tried the No!No! before (HUGE waste of money, plus gross smelling!) so I was a little hesitant to make another hair remover purchase. I read the reviews, most of which said it was not painful and the price tag was fairly decent. I also reviewed some YouTube videos and the girls epilating their legs were smiling so I decided to give it a try.<br /><br />First off, Amazon sent the order to which someone stole my package! I spoke to a representative and they shipped a new one to me to my office. GREAT customer service on that part. Shipping was fast both times and because of the incident, I was able to grow out some hairs for epilation.<br /><br />Once I got it home, I plugged it in and turned it on. The sound is very loud! Like, I am afraid my neighbors were wondering what on earth I was doing. But who cares, they don't need to know I am epilating my legs :p. It looks very scary, as well. Because those little metal graspers move very fast and screech. I put it on my legs.. and OW! Oh my gosh does it hurt! Those YouTube girls must have been drunk or something!!! I had to move it in small circular motions. The pain honestly feels like a burning sensation. Once you get going though (and with many breaks and hesitations around the ankle) the pain starts to become numb. Probably because it hurts so bad. Because I was going so slow ittook me half and hour to do both legs. Once I was done my legs has millions of red bumps all over them, some were bleeding! I rubbed some non-frangranced lotion on them and it felt soothing. I went to bed and in the morning the red bumps were gone and my legs looked AMAZING! They feel so soft from doing it.<br /><br />Some hairs were too short to get picked up from the epilator so I will be doing it again in a couple days. Honestly. I feel that it hurt so bad because I had so many hairs being pulled at once. This next time around it will not hurt as bad. Must buy for those pretty ladies with man hair!<br /><br />Also, I hope whoever stole my package was tortured by this thing!<br /><br />:)

  1162. I purchased this with the intention of using it on my face (even though the directions say not to). I have not gotten the courage to do so. I will not lie, epilating hurts. The only issue I consistently have is ingrown hairs. However, I've found that washing with a cleanser with Salicylic acid and a loofa greatly reduces this issue.<br /><br />I do wish that I had spent a little more money and bought one that was cordless as well. The cord on this one is fairly long, but it tethers you to an outlet. And if your bathroom is anything like mine, a comfortable spot in which to do this is not close to the outlet. So if you're thinking about getting one of these, take that into consideration before you make your final decision.<br /><br />While I don't use this for the purpose I had intended, I am very happy with how it works. I get smooth arms for a couple weeks with just 30 min or so of pain. Maybe one day I'll build up the courage to do my legs.

  1171. Short summary: does the product work? Yes. Longer summary: I am a male. I purchased this item to remove torso hair I did not want from medium to \\"high-traffic\\" skin areas-- no sensitive skin areas. Thank goodness. First of all, the item is White/Gray per the item description, with a pink add-on attachment for first time users/victims: overall, a cute, innocent-looking pink and white device. This, in my opinion, is frankly devious and borders on false advertising. There is a spectrum between discomfort and pain. When I had purchased this item, I had hoped 1) it would work well, and 2) that it would hurt less than Nair or wax treatments. Well, 50% it is. All you women out there, feel free to mock me and men in general for our low pain tolerance, and how most men wouldn't be willing to go through half the discomfort/pain you women go through in the pursuit of beauty each week. Go on, get it out... fair enough. But for me, and I don't think that my wife or others who know me would describe me as a wimp, this device produces a lot more pain than discomfort. Yes, if you use this device only on super high-use skin, the sensation you get stays right on the high end of discomfort, not quite tipping over the cusp into pain. But use it anywhere else? Pain. Picture ripping hair wax treatments off slooowly, pulling hair by hair deliciously out by the roots, all the while listening to a cute little pink device hum along cheerfully. Nowadays, even hearing the humming noise causes me to clench instinctively... So, does this thing work: yes. Use it judiciously, or give it as a gift to an in-law.

  1181. I had never even heard of an epilator before purchasing this, but I hate shaving and waxing so I was looking for an alternative. This product was the number one bestseller in its category on Amazon so I decided to check it out. After reading reviews for about half an hour, I decided to take the plunge.<br /><br />It arrived quickly and I tested it out as soon as I got it. I was scared it would really hurt because of the reviews, but it actually wasn't bad at all. If you've ever gotten a tattoo you'll know exactly what this feels like. Some people compared it to bee stings or other frightening things, but a way better description is just like getting a tattoo. My skin quickly went kind of tingly numb and I didn't even notice the pain anymore (exception to bikini area - that was pretty painful).<br /><br />I used this on my legs, underarms, and bikini area. It worked perfectly everywhere and removed hair with shocking effectiveness. It's been a week now and the hair still isn't back!! The only really unpleasant part of using this was when I went &#34;down under&#34; with it. I wax myself regularly and this didn't feel any different from waxing (and it worked better) but it was a slower motion so it was definitely more painful. It wasn't unbearable though; I was able to complete the upper triangle as well as my bikini line before I called it quits. I think I'll still be using a razor for the really sensitive areas.<br /><br />Anyway, this is by far the best thirty dollars I've ever spent on hair removal and in the long run I think it's going to save me time of money on razors and wax. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone who wants a more convenient and economical method of hair removal, and don't get scared away thinking it'll be super painful! It's definitely worse in your head ;)

  1183. This is my first time using an epilator. I hate shaving, and I hate having to do it so often. I found this epilator and decided to give it a try despite the warnings of pain as it rips out the hair. Sounds scary, huh?<br /><br /> Anyway I plugged it in, hesitated, and then went for it. I felt it pulling the hair, but was relieved that it was not really painful at all. I mean, it wasn't pleasant, but it wasn't agony either. A few seconds into it, and I just went to town making sure I'd covered every square inch. I actually looked for the \\"pulling\\" feeling so that I knew where I had missed. So I honestly don't think it's all that bad. I can't promise everyone else will feel the same way, since I suppose some may be quite sensitive to pain, but I really didn't consider it pain as much as a discomfort.<br /><br /> I even took off that dumb cap, as I'm pretty sure it's only there for psychological reasons...it really doesn't do anything in my opinion. It felt and functioned the same with or without. What really matters, is how hard you press the unit to the skin, and even then, it only affected how well it removed the hair and did not give the nicks or cuts that a shaver would.<br /><br /> So the results? Afterward I had tiny little red bumps where the hair was removed, but they didn't hurt. I put on some natural lotion (one without alcohols or chemical irritants) and within a few hours, smooth legs. I'll likely start exfoliating in the shower regularly to avoid ingrown hairs. If I can get away with longer periods between hair removal with this as compared to shaving, this is totally worth it.

  1197. Okay, lets start with the first thing on everyone's mind in these reviews. I keep seeing a lot of &#34;pain&#34; comments. Let me tell you, if you think you're an expert as a first time user you're wrong.<br /><br /> If you don't listen to the directions, or have patience for trial and error this product isn't for you. My first time using this on my legs it hurt, yes, but not an enormous amount and might I add my leg hair was LONG. NOT RECOMMENDED, I just thought I knew everything! It was a new sensation. I've never &#34;plucked&#34; my legs before. I also left room for error though. I didn't keep the epilator at a hard 90 degrees, I either pressed too hard or not hard enough, and I made it hard on myself.<br /><br />Be PATIENT, everyone is going to use it a little bit differently. I found that on the front of my legs I needed less pressure, and more on the back. I've used this product twice and stopped using the cap because I find life to be far easier without it. Now on use two I already feel little to no pain. This is on both the 1 and 2 settings.<br /><br />Now with my experience stated, let me give you some facts:<br /><br />1. For folks saying it only breaks, and does not remove the hair? If you are too light in the pressure department you will trim your hair and not have it removed fully. It will sting the first time or two. It fades quickly unless you have a very low pain tolerance.<br /><br />2. All of your hair isn't always in the same direction, this is why I'm guessing a lot of folks complain about missing patches? You might have to go over your leg twice at most, but it really does snag any hair you move it over AS LONG AS IT'S THE RIGHT DIRECTION. Always have the button facing the direction you're aiming for. Have it face up toward you for your first stroke, then turn it and go down your legs. I promise you will be impressed!<br /><br />3. Is their a burn or bumps? I experienced little to none. Far less than shaving. FAR less than waxing.<br /><br />4. Using this epilator anywhere other than your legs? TRY AT YOUR OWN RISK. I DO NOT RECOMMEND IT. This is for legs. I've done my thighs, and my inner lower thighs where I get some thicker hairs, and where I have waxed. [Aka where the skin is far more used to this type of sensation so I feel no pain.] I don't recommend using this anywhere other than legs, especially not on super sensitive areas. Bikini isn't so bad, definately not your face. That should just be common sense, but I know someone will try it. [I did. I'm a curious person!]<br /><br />5. Is it worth it? I say 5 stars worth of yes. I'm a woman, I've shaved for a while now and it's not that it's hard, or taxing, and it's no less time consuming than this, but it cuts costs. [No more shaving creme, using extra body wash or buying razors as often. Now I only need one razor for my underarms and genital area and that will last me much longer than if I had to do my legs every night. My leg hair grows very quickly!] Also I live in a small studio apartment with a very tiny bathroom that doesn't leave me, someone with long legs, much room TO shave. My shower is cramped, and the rest of the bathroom is very tight. I prefer to be able to sit and get a close up look at my legs when I shave them! I'm a bit OCD. :]<br /><br />I think this epilator is fantastic. It might take a shake to get used to but it is definately worth it and a great bargain for the price. Get a loofa or a nice exfoliating wash. Don't skip your legs in the shower and it will be clean, painless sailing as long as you're patient for your first few uses, use it as directed, and don't try it on overly sensitive areas. [At your own risk.]<br /><br />Welcome to the wonderful world of no bumps, dry hair removal!Using this epilator anywhere other than your legs? TRY AT YOUR OWN RISK. I DO NOT RECOMMEND IT. This is for legs. I've done my thighs, and my inner lower thighs where I get some thicker hairs, and where I have waxed. [Aka where the skin is far more used to this type of sensation so I feel no pain.] I don't recommend using this anywhere other than legs, especially not on super sensitive areas. Bikini isn't so bad, definately not your face. That should just be common sense, but I know someone will try it. [I did. I'm a curious person!]<br /><br />5. Is it worth it? I say 5 stars worth of yes. I'm a woman, I've shaved for a while now and it's not that it's hard, or taxing, and it's no less time consuming than this, but it cuts costs. [No more shaving creme, using extra body wash or buying razors as often. Now I only need one razor for my underarms and genital area and that will last me much longer than if I had to do my legs every night. My leg hair grows very quickly!] Also I live in a small studio apartment with a very tiny bathroom that doesn't leave me, someone with long legs, much room TO shave. My shower is cramped, and the rest of the bathroom is very tight. I prefer to be able to sit and get a close up look at my legs when I shave them! I'm a bit OCD. :]<br /><br />I think this epilator is fantastic. It might take a shake to get used to but it is definately worth it and a great bargain for the price. Unless its already noticeably long like that weird guy with the mole hair who works at the Chinese buffet in town here for some poorly thought out reason.   1214. Its ok. It was small and the cheapest one so I decided to give it a try. I didn't know what an epilator was so I watched YouTube videos about them. When I finally tried it OMG. It hurt like crazy. I'd honestly rather wax. Its just a machine with a bunch of tweezers pulling out your hairs. The more expensive ones have more tweezers. People say the more tweezers the less it hurts but I'm pretty sure it'll still hurt too. This is something I would recommend to use after a couple days of shaving when the hair starts to grow back. Since its pulling the hair from the root your hair grows back in less time just like waxing. I would say this is something to purchase if your trying to stop shaving and stop ingrown hairs. But you have to be tolerant to the pain.

  1222. Very easy to use and works well. I chose a corded epilator specifically as I dont like dealing with batteries and recharging them.<br />Been waxing for 15 years, and the results of using this epilator are equal.<br /><br />I lay down newspapers on the floor before epilating, so its an easy clean-up. Takes about 20-30 mins to get both legs and hands done.<br /><br />The trick is to always go against the hair growth, so, usually on hands the epilator goes side-to-side, on thighs it goes diagnally. So, always watch the direction of your hair. If you simply go up and down, then you will call for pain for sure.
  1223. This is my first epilator.<br /><br />To women who have never epilated before: This will be painful. Terribly, terribly painful. And to those who risk using this on your bikini line: You are a fool and I am envious of your bravery!<br /><br />My first time, I was forced to do it in small shifts: A few strokes on the legs, then a break. This particular epilator seems to have about 15 sets of tweezers, which is a small area, really, so it is very time consuming and it does not get all the hairs the first time over.<br /><br />Because my underarms stay dark even after shaving, I was hoping this would help, but it still hurts so bad, I think I may have to go back to shaving them.<br /><br />Also, this epilator is easy to clean and is a great size.   1230. Sometimes a product comes along that is so effective, that it deserves accolades. The Philips &#34;Satinelle&#34; epilator, (model HP6401) is very deserving of praise. It does what it claims to do and it does it very well. It permanently removes hair from the human body.<br />As an American male of half Middle-Eastern - half Slavic blood, I have been blessed with thick black hair that grows out of most parts of my body...and now that I am entering my geriatric years, hair has been growing on parts of my body where hair does not belong. While dealing with trimming one's eyebrows, beard and skull-top hair is easily done and acceptable barbershop routine, hair growing out of one's nostrils and on one's ear lobes, including the entrance to the hearing canal requires a more personal approach. The Philips epilator removes this unwanted hair with very little pain and with amazing precision....PLUS I get to do this in the privacy of my home.<br />Before I purchased this device, I either had to individually pluck hairs with a tweaser or cut them with my Norelco three-headed razor. The plucked hairs were very difficult to target and the cut hairs simply grew back. This Philips epilator &#34;cleans&#34; these hairs for once and for all. Any future hair growth, which will occur, is easily attacked and solved.<br />I am very pleased with this product.

  1241. The first time I used this it was horrible. The pain was unreal. I say this as someone that has a very, very high pain tolerance (giving birth, tattoos, didn't bother me). Then I realized I wasn't moving the item fast enough. Staying in one spot too long caused the pain. So I got the nerve to try it again. Perfect timing on my part. If you move it quickly enough, the pain isn't nearly as bad. It isn't painless. It's ripping your hair out of the follicles!<br /><br />As for the results, I am happy. I've used this mostly on my legs. I hate shaving. The knee area, around the sides, and on the back of the knee are very sensitive. However, everywhere else has been great. I haven't seen broken hairs, just a lot of hair gone. After my first round, I had a little bit of redness that went away fairly quickly. I also use washcloths in the shower that aren't super soft, so they help exfoliate and keep me from getting ingrown hairs.<br /><br />If the hair is too short, it will not work well. That's the only downside. However, I know that after repeated use, the amount of hair that grows back will be less than it was before I started.<br /><br />Also, the guard that comes with it is purely for psychological reasons. You can remove it, and it works just fine. The epilating rotating wheel is not sharp and you will not cut yourself. I use it without the shield.
  1242. I waited 2 months to post a review for this, because I wanted to have some experience using the product before rating it. I've used it regularly for the 2 months to epilate from my ankles to my knees. I've found that the hairs have to be at least around 4mm for this thing to pick them up. Shorter hairs just don't get pulled. Additionally, longer hairs can break instead of coming out by the root, and then you are left with a hair too small for the device to pick up. My legs are never smooth after epilating because there are always some smaller hairs / stubble from breakage or just different growth cycle. I do get plenty of ingrown hairs which I have to pluck out with a tweezer as well, even though I exfoliate consistently with exfoliating gloves.<br /><br />On the bright side, I am now noticing much less hair growth than before. I will continue using this for the long term effects of lessening the amount of hair that grows. However, I still have to shave after epilating to get the perfectly smooth skin that I desire.

  1267. So I've seen a ton of reviews on this specific epilator and although there are many good reviews, I'm only concerned with the bad ones. The bad reviews tell me if there's something genuinely wrong with the product or if people are just whining about insignificant things.<br /><br />So to start, ALL EPILATORS HURT! There's no getting around that. This product is no different. This is something you simply have to acknowledge before buying it. For my first time using an epilator, I learned a valuable lesson rather quickly. You cannot run this thing over your body the same you would a washcloth. That will really REALLY hurt. It's far better to work on small areas at a time. I've found that doing a centimeter at a time seems to work the best and is quite tolerable.<br /><br />I've personally found that this epilator works pretty well, so long as you take it slow and easy with plentiful breaks. Doing your legs may be an all night process your first time. But if you take it slow, the pain really isn't nearly as bad as some people make it out to be. Just take it slow and easy. Slow and easy. Seriously.

  1276.   1277. This requires patience, persistence, and a high pain threshold! I have very thick black hair and did little patches at a time until I thinned my hair out enough to tolerate it. I actually had to visualize myself in an interrogation situation and ask myself would I cave over some hairs being pulled out? That got me through, and I'm happy to report it no longer hurts at all. BUT you have to stick with it or it will come back just as thick. It gave me the worst ingrown hairs I've ever seen in my life but regular exfoliation as well as using an alpha hydroxy lotion every day durikng the first few months solved the issue. I'm sure people with lighter, thinner hair would have a much easier time using this product.
  1278. This works! I've been using mine on my underarms (even though the directions clearly say to use on legs only.) I have very dark, very thick underarm hair, that is emphasized by my white as white can get skin. And my underarm hair grows so fast I have to shave everyday, and even still it leaves behind a shadow. So I was so excited to try this. After the first use it took a week and a half, maybe almost two weeks, for my underarm hair to start growing back. And the hair that did grow back is definitely finer and softer. I'm hoping that with continued use the hair will get thinner and take longer to grow back. It did take a while, though, to pull out all the hairs. I epilated both underarms about three times a day for three days before finally getting nintey five percent of the hairs out. (I have a lot of hair, gross, I know.) But each of these sessions were only a few minutes long. I'm sure I could have gotten all the hairs out in one session, but my arm was starting to go numb after holding it up for so long. (I did find that if I laid on my bed and held my arm over my head, that helped keep the blood flowing and my arm from going numb.)<br /><br />A lot of other reviewers said it hurts, and it does, but I thought the pain was totally manageable, and I'm terrified of just a little shot or blood work. I also noticed that the pain was a lot less after the initial epilation. If you can push through the pain, do it! I think it's worth it!<br /><br />I only have two complaints. I wish the head was movable. It was hard getting the right angle to pull hairs out, and I imagine around ankles and knee caps it might be hard to reach hairs there too. Second, now that some hair has started growing back, I've noticed that some follicles seem to grow hair back faster than others. Not that this is the epilators fault. But if I want to wair for every follicle to grow back in, I'm gonna have to wait for my underarm to be thick and full of hair again. Otherwise I have to epilate a bit every day for a few days until I've pulled all of them out again.<br /><br />Overall, I love this and will continue using it. I think the price can't be beat. A six pack of razors costs just as much! It will easily pay for itself.
  1279. it is a great product.
  1280. I was surprised how well this gadget works! I bought this particular one because it has the same number of 4 and 5 ratings as more expensive models. Now I see why: It is very effective at removing hair. In contrast to what the instruction sheet says, I had better results with longer hair (previously unshaven) than with 1/8 stubble. I did have to make multiple passes, but that doesn't make your skin raw like multiple applications of wax will do.<br /><br />As for the pain, that will probably be pretty bad for people who have never had their legs waxed or used an epilator before. I used the original Epilady in the 1980s and found it unbearable. Luckily, I have had my legs waxed many times in the intervening years, so this epilator was not painful for me at all.<br /><br />Do use it in an empty bathtub or over a towel, because you will shed lots of little hairs. Ick!<br /><br />Overall, I recommend this product.

This is very different from shaving, waxing, or hair removal cream. I think the more you use it the better and easier it'll be :)

The one painful time has been SO worth it.. I'm LOVING IT! It's SO much easier to just have to go over my lower legs in the shower and i'm done. No more razor bumps, NO paying for waxing, and i'm sure that my husband is appreciating me not complaining about 'not feeling sexy because I haven't shaved'!

  1352. I don't want to make this review seem too personal or sound like a \\"personals\\" ad, but since this device is used on very \\"discreet\\" parts of the body I might as well disclose all the gritty details. First, let me give a little background history on my experiences with hair removal in general. For anyone who wants to know, I am an African-American female on a quest to find a mechanical contraption or formula that will remove body hair effectively and efficiently. The hair on my body tends to be rather thick/coarse/dark in certain areas such as the armpits, the \\"happy trail\\", and of course the forbidden pubic area. Areas where the hair tends to be more fine are the arms and legs. In the past, I have subjected myself to typical methods of hair removal i.e. (cream depilatories, waxing, and of course shaving). Out of all those options the most hated is shaving, somehow I always end up nicking myself or dealing with constant in-grown hairs. With cream depilatories I often experienced some adverse chemical reaction and with waxing, well, its f@#!ing painful, but probaly the most swift and effective method I've used. However, I have never in my entire life heard of a contraption called an \\"EPILATOR,\\" so this is my first introduction/purchase of an epilator. So you can call me an epilator virgin, but unfortunately I'm not entirely satisfied with my first time. So let's get down to the pros and cons:<br /><br />PROS:<br /><br />- Inexpensive (most epilators are marketed at a very high price point)<br />- Light-weight (even though I have never used an epilator, I just know from personal preference that I do not want to work<br /> with a device that is heavy or awkward.)<br />- Minimal Pain (There was not much discomfort experienced while using this product, but I will admit that the discomfort<br /> intensified while using on more sensitive areas such as the underarms, torso, or pubic area.)<br /><br />CONS:<br /><br />- Ineffective on areas where the hair is thick/coarse/dark. (It took several passes to remove coarser hair.)<br />- Broken Hairs (Some of the hairs were broken and not removed from the root at all, especially when using on areas with<br /> denser hair growth. Fine Hair: 75% removed 25% broken ; Coarse Hair: 55% removed 45% broken<br />- The cleaning brush advertised with the product in the instruction manual did not come with the product.<br /><br />So far, I can tell that this product is probably best used for legs only or areas where the hair is NOT dense/coarse. After reading the instruction manual, I noticed that it is recommended that this product is to be used only on the legs and nowhere else, but obviously I want this product to be effective everywhere not just my legs. Today I still use cream depilatories on my legs that is formulated for sensitive skin and I'm okay with using just that, but my sole purpose for buying this product is to use it for underarm hair and the infamous \\"happy trail.\\" Overall, I'm not 100% satisfied, I will use the product a few more times and give an update, but if I'm not entirely happy with this product I will definitely take advantage of the 45 day full money back guarantee.
