Gets the job done. For me, it hurt like the dickens the first time I did it and I wanted to cry like a baby, and I tend to have a high tolerance to pain. I've since done it consistently once a week, and both times after the first it has definitely been more tolerable.<br /><br />That said, now that I do think I will stick with this method of hair removal, I might upgrade to something else to see if it is more efficient. This does take a bit of time, going over the same area, and hasn't quite succeeded in getting all hair, although it does get most. I have pretty fine hairs, so it may just be me. I won't know unless I try a different epilator, however.<br /><br />All in all, for the price, it works well enough. For a novice, it would be a good first epilator to purchase.
  1369. i had a phillips epilator before this one and it seemed stronger but this one does the job it is smaller than my previous model
  1370. I used the same Epilator for a while this one is my second and I tried other brands before that one is the best ever.
  1371. I had never used an epilator prior to buying this Phillips. My biggest gripe with this product is that it misses too many hairs. I feel like I can sometimes make a dozen passes over a small patch of skin with visible hairs of a length that should be perfect and the hairs are still left standing. I've tried using it both with and without the include guard with the same results. The product just doesn't seem to do what it is supposed to do. For that reason, I cannot recommend it.
  1372. Have used it for several months now, and it works great. Never used a more expensive one, but it's hard to imagine they could work much better than this.
  1373. This is a whole bunch of NO. Just say no. I would not recommend this for anyone besides my worst enemy. It's not for removing hair. It's for torturing prisoners at Guantanomo. It seriously missed about half the hair no matter how many passes and attempts to stand the hair up straight so it all catches. Tried to get rid of some stomach and chest hair. I did about half my stomach and just tried various other spots to see if it would do anything. It leaves a lot behind that simply can't be caught with the auto tweezers but what it does rip out hurts so much it's unbelievable. Within seconds I had massive amounts of sweat dripping out of my arm pits, face bright cherry red dripping sweat, clinched my teeth so hard I thought they were going to break and after a couple minutes my legs felt too wobbly to stand, got light headed, blurred vision and felt the need to lay down. My lips went numb as well like I had that feeling of spider hole face where you can't open your mouth and your lips kinda feel all tight like your spider hole... I guess this is what happens when someone's body goes into shock..? I am not sure but the experience was unforgettable. This product is useless as a hair removal device but amazing as a torture device. Whoever came up with this invention is very sadistic to say the least. Within minutes the areas where it tore the hair out became super inflamed and red, caused open wounds large enough to bleed. Now to be clear, I am no city boy hipster that can't take pain. I work hard all the time pushing my body to the limit and don't shed a tear when injured but this had me in total submission mode. It says to only use on completely dry skin, but it doesn't mention you'll sweat to profusely that it's completely impossible. Had to take a second shower. I may have actually lost weight in the process. All the clinching probably made my abs better. That is a plus. If you can handle this thing, you're one tough feller. After doing this, all I can think about aside from my own mind bending pain is how on earth does a girl do this to her downstairs?? I thought about drinking to see if I could finish but unfortunately it was day time and I had driving to do....darn.
  1374. I've had this epilator for about a year now and I can say it really gets the job done every time I use it. Since then I haven't enjoyed my epilating sessions because it now takes 40 minutes to do my legs, half of which that time is f**king around with the cord to make it work.<br /><br />TIL: the cord it comes with is crap.   1379. Cheaper than a single wax job, and far lower maintenance than shaving. I'm new to epilators, but I've done home waxing and threading before. This does seem relatively low pain - on the legs where my hair is relatively fine, no worse than trying to shave with a scratchy razor. The underarms were killer - remember to pull skin taught, and consider a wax job to get you started. I'm going to guess that because my underarm hairs are coarse, and I have some multiple-haired follicles there, it was a tougher job. It probably has everything to do with your hair's texture and growth patterns. I ventured to try on my chin/lip area, and it worked well, there too. Hair doesn't have to be long, maybe try this a week or so after your last shave for the least discomfort.<br />My first pass did miss some spots, so the next day, I laid a towel out in a well-lit area to do more cleanup. I wound up doing my arms the second day because I'm so satisfied with the effect.<br />As with any hair removal, be sure to exfoliate - I used a gentle glycolic acid scrub before, applied witch hazel toner after, and plan to exfoliate again in the next few days.

I've been converting all of my family and friends to epilating instead of shaving (which is annoying and it grows back way fast) or waxing (which is hot, hurts, iffy on how well it works, and gets everywhere).   1393. I have to confess, I didn't even know such a thing as this existed until about an hour before I bought it. It was an impulse buy that I didn't have high hopes for. When I used it for the first time, I was pleasantly surprised!<br /><br />After reading other reviews, I was a nervous about how painful this would be, because I'm a Grade A wimp. Again, I was pleasantly surprised. I would describe the feeling as an unpleasant nettling sensation that occasionally veers into the territory of bee sting-painful in sensitive areas like the inner thighs. As other reviewers have said, this is perhaps not the most efficient Epilator out there (though I can't speak from experience on that, as I've never used another). I do have to go over the same area sometimes 3 or 4 times before all the hair is gone, so it ends up taking 15-20 minutes to finish both legs. However, it has been a week since I used it and my legs are still silky smooth! This is a huge improvement over having stubble 2-3 days after shaving. In my mind, that's worth the extra time.<br /><br />Like the directions specify, I exfoliate before I use this (though usually just a couple minutes before, not the couple days the instructions recommend). So far, I've had no problem with in-grown hairs or the like.<br /><br />As others have mentioned, the cleaning brush is not included. I don't really know that's it's necessary. The head pops off easily and it's not hard to run it under water or blow on it to get the hair out. I will say that the head doesn't feel terribly secure. Occasionally it pops off while it's running. I don't see this as a big problem, as the same thing used to happen with my old electric razor. Maybe I just like technology with a personality.<br /><br />All in all, this is a useful product that does what it advertises at a fraction of the cost of its competition.

  1428. To start, I am a caucasian female who has lots of experience with waxing. I wanted to try something a bit less messy (and I liked the idea of not waiting until hair is long to remove). The hair on my legs is mostly fine except coarse hair towards the bottom of my calves. I found that this epilator did a good job of removing the coarse hairs, but simply broke the fine hairs off rather than pulling them out. The results were just okay. My legs are not nearly as smooth as waxing or shaving. Nevertheless, this epilator did a fantastic job of removing my coarse armpit hairs. I am currently just using it for armpits and have gone back to waxing for legs. If you have hair like me, you might want to try a more expensive epilator to catch and pull out the fine hairs on your legs. If your hair is fairly coarse all over, this epilator will probably work well for you.
  1429. OK, So I'm new to using epilators. I'm one of those ladies who is \\"blessed\\" with coarse leg hair, and truth be told, I'm really sick of it. I can shave in the morning, and have stubble by night...and I can't tell you how many razors I go through in the course of a month. I originally decided to use MOOM sugaring product, and while it worked well above the knee, I wasn't really thrilled with how it worked on my lower leg. Cue my search online, and I came across some reviews on epilators. After my lower leg sugaring fail, I decided to order the Philips Satinelle epilator based on reviews and price. When I received the product, I thought it looked kind of cheap and lightweight and I was pretty intimidated by the tweezers. I was even more intimidated by the sound and envisioned ripping my skin off with this thing. However, I was ready for some smooth legs and decided to just do it. I am pretty tolerant of pain, but when I turned the epilator on and put it up to my leg, it caught some hair and felt like the sting of some pretty angry bees. I forged ahead, and became immune to the pain after a few swipes on my leg. After starting on level 1, I quickly decided to switch to level 2, and found it to be less painful. There was a learning curve to using this product, holding the skin tight, and figuring out the angle to glide over my leg. Once I saw some hairs coming out by the root.....I was HOOKED! I seriously used the epilator for an hour. When I finally turned it off, I was somewhat disappointed. I felt like I had ripped out a lot of hair, but my legs were still prickly. Some of the hairs I thought ripped out by the root were likely just cut.<br /><br />I am still not convinced that I let my leg hair grow long enough for this to be super effective, so I will keep trying. I have noticed though, that even with some longer hair, this epilator does not grab the hair and I have make several (sometimes painful) passes to remove the hair. But, I have also seen this remove some very short hairs very effectively. I'm kind of perplexed by how that happens, but I'm going to try this product for a few more weeks before really judging its true effectiveness.<br /><br />If you are on the fence about buying this product, I would say go ahead and try it. I'm guessing most people aren't dealing with the same coarse hair I am (thanks mom and dad!). I think there is a 45 day trial period, so you really can't go wrong. Make sure to exfoliate to avoid ingrown hairs. I've had some, but I also get some from when I was shaving, so it wasn't that big of deal to me. I will add that there is no way I can use this product around the bikini area...it is super painful (I think sugaring is faster, easier and far more effective). I have not used on other areas of the body. I will update in a few weeks if I can give this product a higher score...or if I end up getting a pricier model. Good luck!

  1435. It goes without saying that ripping a hair out from the root hurts a lot more than just shaving it. However, if you can steel yourself and work through the pain, the results are great. The first time I used this epilator, it took me a couple of hours just going bit-by-bit, and I only ended up doing just up to my knees. I didn't want to continue because of how long it was taking and how much pain I felt.<br /><br />However, many days later, my half-finished legs are serving as a live before-and-after shot! I ended up shaving what I couldn't epilate, and the results are pretty clear. Below my knees, my legs are smooth as ever. Above, they're already looking like they need a trim so I can epilate the next part, too! The other great thing is that there's no chance of cutting yourself -- I'm a bit clumsy, so this is a big plus for me. I've heard stories about particularly stubborn hairs causing a tiny bit of bleeding (no more than a pin prick) but it's yet to happen to me.<br /><br />So yes. It does hurt, and it's not the fastest solution... but it really is worth it! Since I haven't used it (I didn't need to!) on the same area that I managed to get done again, I can't really tell you if it hurts less the second time around. Even if it did hurt the same amount again, I'd still do it. It's about results!

  1496. From a guy's perspective... This gets 4 stars for now. When I use it in &#34;other&#34; regions, when I get up the courage, with improved results, I will change my rating. Even if you don't buy one of these, I hope you get some comic relief reading my review...<br /><br />Wow! #1: OMG, lol, I felt as if I'd been electrocuted!<br /><br />Let me explain: I have an area on my face where the hair grows out of one spot about 3x faster than the rest of my face. Gross, I know. It's an area about 1/4&#34; in diameter, but it bugs the crap out of me. I originally was going to spend $400 on a NONO, but couldn't bring myself to it. I have seen professional laser removal systems for about $800, and I couldn't do that, either. So, after reading the Philips reviews, I decided to give it a try. I fired this thing up and looked at the spinning discs. I visualized a wood chipper grinding into my face...but decided to try it anyway. After all, millions of women have used this on their legs--how bad could it be? I put this thing closer and closer to my face, and it finally grabbed a couple hairs. Has anyone ever been snapped by a rubber band or one of those novelty joy-buzzers? Have you ever stuck a 9v battery to your tongue??? That's what it felt like on my face--about 10x at once. Not wanting to be a Sally, I kept going on both sides of my face. Let me tell you, I am no sissy, but it hurt. No bloodshed, mind you, but it felt like getting electrocuted by that 9v battery multiple times every time it pulled hairs out of my face.<br /><br />Wow! #2: This thing actually works. I would like to say it doesn't, but it did and does work. Those hairs are coming back in that spot over time, but there are a LOT fewer (less?) of them than before. I had to endure quite a bit of pain (for me) to get the job done, but I'm thinking it was worth it.<br /><br />Wow! #3: The price. I paid about $40 for this corded version. Philips has a $100 cordless version with ceramic discs that I may upgrade to sometime, but this will do for now. Considering I was thinking about paying about 10x this amount for a NONO, I would say it was reasonable.<br /><br />If you buy one, good luck. I just wanted people to know what to expect, at least based on my experiences.

  1500. This is my first epilator. I read the instructions first. I read the tips posted in all of these great reviews. But this product just didn't work for me. I never have been prone to ingrown hairs, but (from what little hair this item actually did pull out) that's what appeared. My husband freaked out wondering how I got all these horrible red bumps on my legs...and they were still hairy! It was kind of humiliating. I'm glad I tried it first during a cold Minnesota winter, so my legs can be comfortably covered while they heal. I tried it on longer hair. I tried it on shorter hair.   1501. It's effective, but only if you know how to use it correctly. As a first-time epilator user, it took me awhile to figure out what exact angle and distance works best for my hair type- don't give up if you botch the first time; I kept clipping hairs instead of pulling them from the root and thought my device was defective. A few more tries and I got the hang of it. That adjustment period goes for everyone, though I think if you buy a fancier model they might be more intuitive to use. My one gripe with this model is that I always have to repeatedly go over areas to get them completely clear, so as a result epilating is a much longer (and painful) process than shaving. But given the results, and having nothing else in the epilating world to compare it to I'd still give it 4 stars.<br /><br />I find it most effective for my underarms. Did it hurt like a mother and bleed the first time I tackled that area? Sure did. But it's made a HUGE difference in the thickness and texture. Shaving always left me with a five-o'clock shadow look at the end of the day- even newly shaved, you could still somewhat see the dark roots. Not cute. But once I suffered through that first time, the hair grew back thinner, and by the second time it was much easier to remove. Definitely boosted my confidence with wearing sleeveless tops.<br /><br />That's pretty much how epilation goes anywhere you try it. Hell the first time, then it gets better. If you naturally have finer body hair, that starting pain threshold will be respectively lower.<br /><br />As others have stated, hair/skin needs to be dry, and you have to let your hair grow out some between epilations so they are accessible to the tweezer blades, but I'd also add to that don't wait too long or it will be more painful. I still hate epilating my legs- too painful, and takes too long. For them I still get tempted to shave. One of these days I might upgrade to something that can get them in one go. This is a good, affordable starter modelthough that can help you test the waters and see if epilation works for you.

  1518. Purchasing this epilator was not an easy decision for me. The fact that it sounds painful didn't appeal to me but I knew it I had to buy since I was getting irritated of having to shave my underarms twice in the same day (I actually bought the epilator for my underarms instead of my legs). Okay, so let's get this over with, questions I wanted to know before I bought this was:<br /><br />1.Will it hurt? -A: Yes it will hurt. It pulls out hair from the root, of course it's going to hurt. How much will it hurt? It depends on how well you handle pain but yes, the more you use it, the more you'll get use to it and soon you'll feel nothing at all. The pain wasn't honestly as bad as I thought it was going to be. If you want to have an idea on how it'll feel, try pulling out the hair from your desired-to-be-hairless-soon area with a pair of tweezers. Now imagine that sensations but triple (actually has 5 of them) cause this epilator has more the one but again, you'll get use to it. I only felt the pain the first two times I used it. I actually removed my underarm with tweezers before I epilated (yeah, ew) so I think that's the reason it didn't hurt so much and just felt little pinches instead. So try it if you want to know your pain tolerance.<br /><br />2.How fast does it go? -A: Very fast. There are two speed settings on this thing \\"for thin hairs and difficult to reach areas\\" (says so on the back of the box). I have only used the 1st settings because it already seemed very fast and the couldn't imagine how the second one felt like. My first reaction was \\"Jeezes!\\" before quickly turning it off. Though now that I'm used to epilating, for some reason I have yet to use the second setting and questioning myself why as I write this. Either way, it was fast enough for me to be chicken before trying it. It was already midnight before I could bring myself to do it only to find myself feeling silly over nothing.<br /><br />3. How loud is it? -A: It's loud enough for someone to askyou what you're doing. Though it was louder than I thought it would be but not loud enough to wake up my brother after closing the bathroom door (though he is a heavy sleeper). Don't worry, it's not loud enough to wake up your neighbors.<br /><br />4. How messy will it get? -A: It depends on the areas you want to epilate but whether its the arms, legs, underarms or back, they all have one thing in common the hair will not magically put it self in neat pile. The hair will go everywhere. If you're planning to do your arms and legs, I suggest you epilate in the bathtub because it will get messy. Real messy.<br /><br />5. How to start? -A: Before using the epilator, you will need to shave the area. Wait 2-3 days for the hair to grow so the epilator will be able to grab the hairs. Don't have the hairs to long on the epilator will just break the hair which would be the same as shaving.<br /><br />6. How well does this epilator work? -A: Out of 10? A 7.5 since it does a decent of grabbing many of the hairs but I never have a completely hairless armpit without having a few tiny hairs left behind. Usually 2-4 hairs left but you can just use a set of tweezers to remove them. It does, however leave your area feeling smooth like a babies bottom. For the rest, you can read on the instructions that comes in the box.<br /><br />7. Will I get ingrown hairs? -A: If you don't exfoliate you probably will. On the day after first time, make sure to clean the area that you epilated which you can do in the shower. You can epilate after a shower but make sure your legs/arms/armpits are dry before epilating.<br /><br />8. What does the box (actually) come with? -A: Box comes with charger, efficiency cap, instructions and of course, the epilator. It comes with everything the box says it does, except for the brush to help remove hair from the epilator. Couldn't find it in the box but it wasn't a problem since I had a brush similar and just used that one instead. The box actually looked likeit have been opened but I didn't care as long as it come with the major stuff (bought it from Amazon).<br /><br />So to finish off this review, I would like to say that I don't regret buying this epilator, though it's my first one and I don't have others to compare to, I like it. I don't have to shave anymore as long as I have this baby. My pits feel smooth and I am satisfied. If you haven't epilated before and shaving irritates the crab out of you then buy this epilator at least for first timers it does a decent job. Good luck and hope you achieve your hairless goals.

  1533. You'll need to get used to the feeling of multiple tweezers plucking out hairs by the roots. After a while your skin becomes accustomed to it and won't be as sore. You'll see some redness but it goes away. My hairs grow back more sparsely than before I began using this epilator. I had used an ancient version of this device in the early '80s called The Epilady - not comfortable at all.
